headline: Good org but culture issues
pros: The HSBC brand is pretty good on the CV. Very structured and highly corporate culture. Opportunities to move across teams, geographies once settled in. Internal movement encouraged.
cons:
Micromanagement of staff time shows a culture of distrust. Extremely process driven and highly bureaucratic. Corporate culture in the extreme.
Stingy company when it comes to salary, hikes etc.
Ops heads and teams have extreme cost cutting plans .
Work quality is average.

headline: Cancel culture
pros: Some company benefits, SAYE, LIfe insurance
cons:
No opportunities to grow or develope these are heavily invested in the Graduates. 

Promotes Mental wellbeing but doesn't deliver, support options are limited and don't expect support from senior managers you'll get a generic HR response.  

Be prepared to work hard but unwillingly give the credit to your managers. Those who work hard get less and unless you constantly blow your own whistle you won't get recognised. 

Expect to get low performance grade for any authorised absence such as Maternity leave even if you've been a top end performer for as long as you can  remember.  

Performance goals aren't always achievable be prepared to be greeted with cancel culture if you happen challenge them. 

If you decide to work for the company use your time wisely and get all the experience and skills you need to move on as you'll have a short shelf life. 

Don't be fooled by the benefits you get NONE, work perks is the biggest con, you actually get a better discount through the retailer. You don't get any staff discount on any of the products either.  There are better competitors out there.

headline: Stable company but too slow moving
pros:
- Pensions
- Bonus at the end of the year which most tech companies don't do
(can't really think of much else that counts as "Pros, which isn't a good sign)
cons:
- As a software product manager, definitely don't join HSBC Digital (or whatever it's called now as they rebrand every 18 months) unless you are in your fifties and looking to just have any job before you retire
- Slow slow moving company trying to digitise its analogue processes
- Doesn't understand innovation in the B2C retail baking software space
- Lots of colleagues were "B players" not doing their best and just there for the stability, leaves at 5pm without caring about the quality of what they do.
- Too many people doing "busy work" that has no end user benefit. Perhaps 50% of the staff can (or indeed should) go elsewhere so they can actually find enjoyment in what they do rather than pretend to do useful work at HSBC.

pros: Decent benefits package, BUPA, Pension etc
cons: Huge pay range for the same role which has very little to do with performance and more to do with when you joined the company. Disappointing that loyalty is not rewarded.

cons: Always eroding pay with inflation, bell curve performance grading process no matter the size of the team. Far too much offshoring constantly refers to moving jobs from high cost (UK & HK) to low cost (india, china) with “Transformation program” seems to be constantly running every year and putting employees under threat of redundancy (UK IT). Very rare and limited training opportunities - even in industry standard processes (ITIL, AGILE, DEVOPS) uses terms like “resource” & “ FTE” to describe their employees - makes me feel unvalued personally. Senior managers I’ve encountered can often say one thing and do the complete opposite. EXAMPLE: Mid Jan 2022: told directly- no redundancy this year and your team is core going forward. mid Feb 2022: redundant by end of Q2 2022.  pay often falls below 90% of median which is reviewed (communicated)  every other year and doesn’t seem to matter if plans are pay freezes across whole “global career bands”

headline: Risk and control;
cons:
Managers: Don't expect heads/managers to have professional risk qualifications i.e. FRM. Based on encounters, they have been long enough with organization so it’s all about visibility to the top, delegating and forwarding inputs gathered here and there. It’s all about upward management and looking out for themselves, in a way that of opportunistic leadership style.  One would think they are focusing on higher-value activities like building relationships paving ways for their team members to obtain inputs and focusing on assignments but that's not the case.  

Hard to get things done without a network. Often ended using cross-functional colleagues to get things done as the internal department is oblivious. If you are in this area, you are better off working without a team structure i.e. single individual contributor.  Colleagues who are individual contributors have stayed longer.

Pay and Promotions: Promotion within this team is near impossible so do reconsider if you are ambitious or experienced.  Other banks have better risk and control functions and do pay well.

headline: I wish it could be the best place to work as they always claim!
pros:
- Stable job
- Brand Name
- Not bad Salaries
- Vacation policy
- Profit share
cons:
- Not a learning environment at all. They don't invest in their people and only depend on the usual E-learning reminders.
- Salaries are good but not competitive specially that they don't provide any type of bonuses throughout the year. It's only one time bonus ( profit share) by the end of the year.
- No career path nor fair promotions are provided. You will find hundreds of staff members are doing the same job, having the same bands for 10+ years. They don't have any promotion/ development plans for any of the employees.
- Work load is horrible due to the lack of the needed number of FTEs. They apply the cost reduction policy all the time.
- They don't have good retention plans for the good ones! If you want leave just leave! All they can do is to get your exit interview done and submitted on system without taking any further actions neither to the employees who decided to leave nor to enhance the current status for the existing ones.
- Turnover has increased lately due to all the mentioned reasons above.

headline: Complex yet inclusive, slow-moving yet impactful
pros:
Great commitment to D&I and ESG globally
235k employees over 65 countries- you can move anywhere and find a job doing anything
Competitive salaries
Great learning and development opportunities with in-house HSBC University courses
Good social mobility from frontline roles into head office roles, keeps customer relevant
Great graduate and internship opportunities
cons:
Very complicated organisation, difficult to grasp the structure
Risk-averse by nature, makes change slow
Asia-focus yet HQ in London makes political direction tricky sometimes
Very white male dominated at senior levels
Good salary and retention levels makes for less dynamism in job roles

headline: If you dont have anything else, then go for HSBC
pros:
Work life balance
Supportive peers
People are supportive when taking leaves
Good leave plan
Good for mid level management
Good if you start with a good salary as there is not much growth.
cons:
Really redundant technology, if you think that the tech you are working on is going to be obsolete, at HSBC it is a new technology.
You can get teams like Mainframe or Service Ticket Resolution which are dead end for your career
A lot of teams have budget issues especially during appraisal cycle.
0 HR involvement
Manager dependent appraisal and not work dependent 
Not a lot of development projects, mostly support projects.
Really slow career growth
Great mismatch between the quality of work done by HTI team and the offshore teams in UK and US.
Managers living in denial and failing to notice issues

headline: Good things about HSBC
pros:
I am working in GBM HK department and I really love to work here.
1. The company provides IT staffs a lot of training and material to grow up our skills, such as free O'reilly access, LinkedIn courses, and coursera
2. The medical scheme here is well covered
3. It provides mortgage discount
4. The direction of senior changed to focus on innovation. It means that team can try out a lot new things, such as AI, blockchain, etc.
5. Colleagues here are very helpful. Knowledge sharing is very common. There are many confluence pages from many different teams that you can learn from.
cons: 1. Difficult to get promoted

headline: Good people, bad hardware and training
pros: Great team, a chance to take part in volunteering and getting for that 2 days off in a year. There is an increment, but it was quite cut last year. There is an annual bonus, private healthcare and cashback for home-office furniture and a chance to borrow screens from the office
cons: There is no foreseeable future for hybrid work or to come back to the office. I was the first person to work on new hardware which was a disaster no one could help with which was the weakest link. The training was really poor and I feel undertrained and unprepared for daily tasks despite my buddy and great Team Leader. From KYC Analyst we were supposed to become Case Managers with much greater responsibility and no compensation until I hand in my notice...

headline: Good company - typical retail banking position
pros:
1) Clearcut expectations/metrics/KPI's. 

2) Most people were friendly.

3) Excellent training and onboarding program (great networking opportunity to make new friends)

4) Abusive behaviour from clients is not tolerated
cons:
1) HSBC pays a below-average salary compared to other FI's.

2) Very archaic system with constant empty promises on it being upgraded.

3) I personally had a horrible manager who was vindictive, abusive, and terribly inexperienced, but I don't think that was the case (generally) across my region.

4) It IS a bank after all, so you will deal with the normal BS associated with any other bank. Endless policies and procedures, top-heavy leadership, promotions are always tenure based and never performance based, hierarchical, political, etc.

headline: Unless a favourite person the opportunity size non existent
pros:
Great pension
Good pay
Global company with internal job role
Great Share plan
cons: Senior leadership have their favourites if your not amongst them you will not progress upwards. Glass ceiling is managed by those internally and they encourage those to move down pay/seniority grade banding levels frequently. Internal roles are suppose to be fair but senior leaders mark out roles for their favourites. Lack of diversity and no real system to change this. It is is only for the performance outward display sake of it. Progression is not based on merit but by how many years you have been at the company. Very old school practices and is not open to the current change. Marketing is appeared to be more progressive as their is more female leaders however they are still lower in the grade banding than their male counter parts and are really an acting middle management. The female senior leaders still enforce the glass ceiling ironically onto the other females that are non British or from other ethnic backgrounds. The company is full of old school practices that frankly won’t change in this lifetime until the veterans of HSBC lifers are retired and a new mindset of leads takes over.

headline: Poor HR. Doesn't care about its employees, slow system, hypocritical management
pros: Great reputation, global bank, lots of money and revenue and probably won't get laid off due to Covid
cons:
Management only care about targets and expect you to work until you pass out. Great place to work overtime WITHOUT PAID. Management will change your hours even you get to input overtime. 
After I left, I wanted to get my T4 and last pay stub as I did not have access to the internal system anymore. Raised 5 cases through HR call centre (in the span of 2 months) and still did not get to have my statements. HR will close the case on their own without notifying former employees. 
Really wish CEO could read this as everyone at our branch wants to leave.

headline: Work Culture & Growth
pros: Brand Value and Good Learning Resources ( although the second point is given by almost all big organisations)
cons:
Following are the list of cons as per my experience with scenarios for you to decide:-

1) Poor Work Life Balance- I was working as Software Engineer in a Department of HSBC wherein they followed mostly traditional waterfall project management model to run projects and these are not efficient as compared to other project management techniques like Agile (Scrum, XP) in terms of managing project timelines, scope updation during project and mainly over-utilizing the resources (team members). Hence, it leads to poor work life balance of the team members.

2) Pay not upto expectations- As per my tenure there hikes are pretty low (around 3-4% pa)

3) Biased Management- I was hired as graduate and they hired for two types of profiles (Strikers - 7 LPA and Acers - 16 LPA). The distinction they made in these two profiles was Strikers were meant to give basic support in projects while Acers were meant to give basic support and play lead roles in projects. But in practice, the type of work Strikers and Acers did was pretty much the same (Really no difference in these two profiles apart from pay). Also, in the next appraisal cycle, Acers got pretty good hike (around 20-30%) while Strikers good pretty low (around 2-3%) creating further gap in their pays. Hence, the management is biased and I didn't really understand their basis of this discrimination.

4) Not much to learn in a long run career perspective- The department where I worked used pretty obsolete technologies like AS/400, Mainframes which are still used in 
many banks due to security and other reasons but as an individual you won't get much to learn and grow as compared to the fast growing technologies in software industry. Also, as per my experience, the bank is not much ready to evolve to better technologies so easily. (I don't know why??) But, as an individual you won't evolve here.

5) Bad Work Environment in terms of people (This is just based on my experience) - The team where I worked was not that efficient in having healthy discussions internally or contribute to solve problems (It was mostly copy and paste others work.. ). Also, there was too much individualism (depending on one individual) instead of collective collaboration (team owning the task) for any task. There was no cross collaboration across teams (I don't know maybe because of too much complicated rules/processes to communicate across teams). Lastly, bad office politics like blaming each other, not having healthy discussions, misuse of power among the hierarchy and senior management not helpful to resolve concerns of employees.

headline: My review
pros:
- Ok benefits
- Some (not all) people are nice
- Chill and relaxed atmosphere
cons:
- Some co-workers are very difficult to work with. Especially the ones that have been in the company for a long time, and will mock you and give you a hard time when you need help or advice
- You are thrown into the deep end on day one, and not given much help
- Poor documentation everywhere, you will literally pull your hair out to find information and find out what team can assist you
- Senior management doesn't care about you or your team unless there is an issue that would make them in trouble, only then they will assist
- Things are very very slow-moving
- Hesitant to move to the cloud 
- Since there is not much help from others and team-members on how to do things and gain information, you often feel like breaking down
- No team/company vision passed down, and as a result, morale is very low
- Very lazy and useless people, that are freeloaders. Give them a task or ask, they never do it, or come up with excuses to not do it, and get a free paycheck

headline: Okay and challenging at the start, but detoriarated due to bad management just before and after merger of Gb/Cmb banking
pros:
New office is nice.
Encourages internal movement.
cons:
-Pay is low compared to the market and upon multiple meetings to discuss unhappiness across the department, management concluded that we must 'do more with less'. - - - No effort done to increase resources, just hiring more offshore with low quality work in work the onshore ppl have to clear their mess.
-New senior management (heads) are always talking about improvements and achievements during meetings but nth has been done so far. Mind you, resource issues were raised as early as Jan 2021 but up till Q3 nothing was done, resulting in staff burnout and mass resignation.
-Front office staff are also reasonable and rude, does not care about MO/BO lack of resources. Escalating to the department bosses just for little issues and sometimes even forcing staff to work till ungodly hours while they knock off early/have frequent coffee breaks.

headline: HSBC-Then and Now
pros: Whatever positive image I had of the company has been shattered the way my brother is being treated
cons:
The managers unnecessarily shout at my brother, mock him in front of the entire team and taunt him before everyone. All his leaves have been cancelled stating workload, there is no one to help him just because he is from a different region then others and can not speak their language. The managers never motivate him and speak like a servant to him. He was not given permission to go visit a doctor. On weekends too he is called and asked to work and if he fails to answer a call he is shouted at in front of the entire team.

The Department in question here is CMB KYC.

headline: good remuneration, system and environment can be improved
pros:
- they are quite generous with the remuneration to attract talents
- good team lead who has very good sense of the overall business
cons:
- bank system is super old and IT has no priority and intention to upgrade or change the system, everything is so backwards and manual for a MNC bank
- colleagues are not very patient with new joiners, expecting you to know after telling you the steps once, they like to push you to read procedure manual, when you reach out to clarify
- procedure manual is not very user/new comer friendly which is very outdated (some of the process kept changing but was not updated) and kept very brief, only people who has been doing it understand what is going on
- constant reshuffling/reorganisation of the team

headline: Avoid if joining as a Software Engineer out of college
pros: Work life balance seemed to be good.
cons:
No growth, below market level pay, In fact it can't even be compared to the tech divisions of other banks which pay competitively like other tech companies. Don't expect this place to be at par with GS, Morgan, Deutsche in terms of career opportunities and compensation.

No wonder a lot of people leave after 1 yr or so.

There's good chance that you might not get proper software development work. Hence even if you neglect the compensation part, career wise to it's not a great position to be in.

headline: A global bank in name
pros:
Health cover and benefits are good, especially compared to the cost of paying for these benefits out of your own pocket.
You will have access to a network of people with a vast array of international experience, which is great for learning about what happens outside of your country and expanding your own horizons. This can lead to opportunities overseas.
cons: Pay reviews have been poor in recent years, and it is easy to stagnate unless you are fast tracked or are motivated to progress your career. Even in the case of the latter there are no guarantees. It really depends what you want and expect from a career here, and also input from your line Managers.

headline: Good to start career, hard to make impact at scale
pros:
- Help you to discover area of interest. I didn’t know what I wanted to do straight after graduation, so I went for a retail banking graduate scheme at HSBC UK, I was lucky to get some good rotations and then decided to switch to data 
- Good work life balance - people are nice and chill, very rarely do an entry level grad (at least for teams I worked with) need to work over time, data team can sometimes be busier, but still very chill compare to other companies
- can work on big projects with strategic importance
- can get involved in very hybrid projects in certain teams, good to get data skills, i.e. you could be a full-stack data person, from initial analysis with visualisation to sketching out machine learning solution and productionising it to make real customer impact then monitoring the metrics throughout the product lifecycle/ upgrading through different iterations
cons:
- Hard to align incentives of different teams. Teams are very specialised, and one project typically include many internal/ 3rd party vendors, and they all have different priorities. So one project can hardly progress according to its planned timeline
- Broken data pipeline because systems are in migration all the time, which increases dependency on other teams and you return to problems in above point
- Unclear career ladder. My department only has junior and senior level and the gap between these two levels are big and hard to define + project delivery is very slow, there seems no decently quick track to progress to higher position
- Salary is not competitive for data roles (of course this depends on your team, this is just what I’m having now!)

headline: Great People, Terrible processes
pros: The people at the branches are usually great and strive to work well together. Manager are very supportive and positive for the most part. They also encourage growth within the company
cons: Inefficient processes mean that the branch is responsible for short comings of all other teams who take NO ownership of customer issues. for all issues, customers are re-directed to the branch or the branch is asked to contact the customer and no other team will take ownership of issues. telephone banking will often decline to service customers and send them into the branch for no reason, or even mis inform customers that they do not need appointments for things like account openings, which results in terrible customer experience at the branch and a devastating blow to staff morale.

headline: Poor Branch management, expect employees to work nom-stop and overtime
pros: Good benefits, world renowned bank.
cons:
Branch management is really poor. Assistant manager will yell at newbies and makes everyone uncomfortable. Turnover rate at our branch is really high due to the work load. Constantly short-staffed and branch doesn’t care or nor did they find new staff immediately. Everyone is working for 2-3 people’s jobs. Management only wants to exceed the KPIs with limited staffs. Staffs are working unpaid overtime every day although manager tells us to leave on time. Other branch’s managers actually kick people out of the office at 6pm but we need to stay because of the workload. 
It is also absurd how they treat walk-ins, as everyone is fully booked and managers still expect walk-ins to get accommodated and we have to leave “on-time”. Other branches will just tell clients to book an appointment and come back, not sure why this branch only cares about performance but not employees mental life and work life balance.

headline: Dominated by Group
pros: Good work culture and work life balance with a lot of diversity - especially in terms of nationalities. Fair level of lateral mobility across departments and geographies.
cons: Limited opportunities to grow especially beyond Band 4 roles. A fair amount of politics and a lot of decision making by the HQ in London which isn't always up to date on ground level issues in local markets. Group takes a one-size fits all decision making approach that usually doesn't work and needs to be re-purposed for use locally causing headaches and general red tape. You need patience!

headline: Ambitious people need not apply
pros: If you were not fortunate enough to go to university and obtain a degree in your chosen field HSBC will take you on as branch staff even casually and you will be able to work up from there. Not via talent or hard work but from connections you can make. HSBC doesn't look at employees results or credentials rather who you know, who are related to or who you have married.
cons: Low levels of communications, process and lack of accountability from management and staff. The complex systems and lack of communication makes it easy for staff to hide mistakes or issues. Local market has very little control of anything that is done. If you want a role were you can have purpose you will need to work in Hong Kong or London. Promotions and roles are provided to staff that managers like and many times roles are not advertised but provided to those they have offered behind closed doors. If dishonesty and gaslighting go against your values, then this isn't the place for you. However if you are able to justify poor behavior then you will go far. CEO has acknowledged that pay is below industry average. In conclusion, systems, pay, communication and management are poor. - are you desperate enough to work here?

headline: Not Disability Confident. Head of HR, CEO Ian Stuart, Noel Quinn haven't replied back to letters, even 1 year later
pros: Variety of roles for starting career as graduate, then look at other companies for career growth.
cons:
Senior Team Management are not engaged with their staff, not interested in keeping you there long term, even if you have worked there over 10 years. 

Very Self-focused environment, rather than building a great team community in the workplace. 

Management team not available for support if you have a problem, they don't come back to you at all and are difficult to get hold of them, even though they tell you to give them positive feedback for their staff survey appraisal, tell you which boxes to tick for the questions that apply to them. 

Sadly not a place where females can thrive, very few opportunities in this decade, even development programmes as female management. 

Not flexible if you want to work part-time in management role as a woman, very rigid, old fashioned.

They are not transparent on salary, hide benefits from you, stop you from talking with other peers and women are not on the same pay as men for same grade. Other employees advertise more honestly and you know what you will be getting as its all on the job posting. 

Didn't look after staff at all over Covid, made lots of job cuts and didn't provide furlough at all, even though the Government made this specifically available for businesses to use and to help their employees, this in itself says a lot about this brand, when other smaller organisations such as NFU did not make any job cuts at all. In the media they ran adverts to say how they are helping over Covid, but behind doors reality is a different story. Not honest in the media that they didn't use Furlough and that they cut jobs. 

I would recommend candidates to invest in a brand which is more up to date with Modern times, as they will struggle to hold onto good staff (this isn't the place for millennials who are ambitious and for women who want to progress), has ethical practices in place in the workplace, transparent and cares about how it treats its staff.

cons: Mediocre culture in the organization, being competitive is not encouraged. Too many layers in decision making and heavy hierarchy that sometimes twisted the mentality of staff from being business oriented to political oriented. Pay is only average or even below the market in some countries. Only HSBC in Hong Kong and the UK are worth working for, in other places the bank is too small to be noticed. Too many negative news now.

headline: How Simple Becomes Complicated
pros:
Hand on heart, decent company culture with most of the senior managers truly passionate about diversity and inclusion. The UK retail bank is making great strides to become a financially inclusive brand that cares about the vulnerable in society. 
The company embraces flexible working, should you in a head office role, part-time, condensed hours, job share, flexible start/finish time, sabbatical, and the number of days in office are all open for discussion with your line manager.

From personal experience, there are plenty of line managers that are passionate about your development and really care about your wellbeing. You may call this luck, but remember, recruitment is a two-way thing. Try to learn about the job, team, and department beforehand, and my humble advice is to choose a good team and/or line manager over fancy titles.
cons:
How Simple Becomes Complicated is a well known phrase in HSBC. 
The executives have spent years trying to streamline and simplify, but the truth is: multiple layers of governance meetings are taking over everyone's time, and teams' responsibilities still overlay each other. 
With the recent job cuts, most departments are operating under bare skeleton. A lot of fire fighting on the ground every day.

This organisation rewards tenure over talent. Unless you started on a graduate scheme, you may usually find colleagues below your grade who has been with the Bank for 20/30 years earn more than you do. This obviously will discourage young talents to stay with the Bank and look for opportunities elsewhere.

headline: Once bitten, twice shy ...
pros: Fairly nice building, good pension contributions and holiday allowance
cons: Took 3 months from interview to joining - most other banking jobs have sorted this within a couple weeks. And I only had 1 interview. Lots of bureaucracy, treatment/ culture is very different across teams - mine team was particularly petty/ clique orientated (I wish I'd done more than 1 interview!). Strangely wasn't 'allowed' to WFH (even though other contractors regularly could), wasn't allowed to speak to my manager's boss or get definite answers on holiday dates even when no one else had booked any time off with one example of requesting a week for a family summer holiday and only getting approval for some of the days. After I left all of the Band 4's under my manager transferred to other teams or left HSBC due to the toxin culture within the team.

headline: Benefits are key
pros: Benefits are honestly amazing. Sometimes makes it worth it all. Your direct line manager is amazing & will do everything in their power to support you. Great team dynamics .
cons: Literally everything else. Above your direct line manager, management don't care about you & let you know this on a daily basis. They make changes that almost never work which causes chaos. If they do respond to feedback, it's so slow & by the time it's implemented, it's out of date. Abuse off of customers is horrendous, from death threats, racial abuse & all sorts of other horrific things. You're expected to just get on with it. Upper management talk about mental health & how much they do, but it's empty words. They try to show how diverse & inclusive they are but its superficial & concerns aren't taken seriously. You're made to feel like it's your fault for interpreting it 'incorrectly'. Staff outside of BTB speak to BTB as if they are dirt beneath their shoes. You'r expected to do ABCDEF but given no support & very little guidance. They will not train you no matter how much you ask, always making up excuses as to why you cannot be trained on more lines. Keeping in mind, that if you are trained on all lines, you can move up a grade level. They have also recently gotten rid of this accreditation meaning you're stuck at the lowest level. Software & procedures are out of date, slow & difficult to use. You are not a bank worker so are expected to work bank holidays. Shifts are badly designed so at times you can be the only person from your management group on the phone. Referrals for customer questions are painful - half the time there is nobody available to answer so you're waiting 5 minutes +. Other half of the time, depending on who answers, you'll have a different solution. The job is mentally & emotionally draining.

headline: Too large and bureaucratic
pros: Great pension and benefits. HSBC is it's own world with vast career opportunity, you could spend your entire working career in various roles and departments, (and many people do).
cons: Suffers from its size. Central functions v global businesses v regional governance across thousands of people and layered hierarchy results in an incredibly bureaucratic organisation where senior leadership is so far removed from the real issues that they're left managing by spreadsheet, powerpoint and email rather than being able to truly value it's people to focus on outcomes and deliver true value. It's an ingrained culture across most of the organisation that's nobody's fault, but it's an almost impossible problem to solve at that scale without radical change and leadership. It's unlikely to come under any genuine threat from challenger banks anytime soon so there's little impetus to make the necessary changes in any reasonable timeframe.

headline: Great benefits, hugely inefficient, full of bureaucracy
pros:
Fantastic work life balance

Great gym and canteen

Not aggressive culture both in terms of people and redundancies
cons:
My particular team was one of the worst I had experienced. 

We had a turn over of 100% staff in the team every year. This included contractors and full time staffers. Contractors would come and stay for 6 months and no more. Team manager and manager's manager was particular bad:

1) Boss would watch our tea breaks. When we come back from tea break he would always give us work. If contractor left early he blocks them at the lift and told them to go back to desk. 

2) Boss himself did no work and was on the phone with recruiters the whole time looking for work himself, at the same time trying to make sure we were all glued to our desks. We say him downstairs on the phone and even sitting at a cafe having tea with recruiters during office hours. 

3) Colleague bought a flat. Asked if he could buy some fx fwd at the time to hedge against Brexit. Boss ignored him. Brexit happened. His mortgage was in euros, he was earning pounds. Pounds crashed. 

4) Contractor found a new job. Out of politeness he told boss he was happy to stay for a few weeks to help with transition. Boss had a chat with his boss and next day told him this would be his last day. He didnt have enough money to pay for his downpayment as he was buying a property and needed the last couple of weeks of pay. In the end had to borrow money from one of us. 

Too many stories in my team. Any wonder that our team's turn over was 100% every year?

headline: HSBC North America
pros:
Amazing colleagues - the people, not the processes get things done. The culture among the folks that move the needle is excellent. 
Genuine engagement around social causes - really walk the walk and not talk the talk.
Ahead of the curve of flex-time / wfh
Would "recommend" to a friend with major caveats.
cons:
A lot of institutional barriers - internal moves are the result of good politics and seldom competence.
Salaries are competitive, bonuses are not.
Unless you are in HK or the UK, you are a secondary / tertiary market and treated as such. Often "central" orders roll out and by the time they arrive in a local market are not recognizable because of too many people opining along the way. Result: a LOT of paper-pushing work

headline: HSBC Review
pros:
Good benefits package, flexible working and superb pension as well as career scope matching an enormous global employer. 
Also, the technology and delivery exposure in an organization of this size is significant. Your opportunities to learn and grow would not be stifled.
Support through Covid has been exemplary as far as I can see, certainly from personal experience and this ethos runs through most areas of management.
cons: the size of the organization means that change, career advancement and process evolution can seem to take forever to come about - big cogs turn very slowly, to the point of pulling ones own hair out.

headline: Great Work Place. Slow Growth
pros:
Great Work-Life balance.
Not much work pressure. 
Flexible working hours. 
Understanding management, especially very helpful in pandemic times.
cons:
Very slow growth. I haven't got my first promotion even though I have finished 2 years 6 months and there aren't any talks about it either.

The annual hike is extremely low. I have got a 2.5% and 5% hike in the last 2 consecutive years and this is above average for the company.

IT Infrastructure is bad. I have struggled a lot to get a good laptop from the company. I was made to work on my own laptop for a significant amount of time.

cons: Culture is not good here..no appreciation for work..favouratism can be seen across all depts.. ijps all are an eye wash. They talk about speak up culture. The moment you speak you will be suppressed. Leadership is a big problem here. You will find all managers and leadership sitting and holding the position for long long years. You will not find a new outlook in managers who can think differently. Because they have not worked in difficult cultures hence not used to it. There should be mandatory rotation of people managers who get fresh minds on board.

headline: Has potential, but let down by culture / management
pros:
- Lots of data science projects happening here, and a sensible tech stack is used with industry standard tools (Python, SQL, etc). Infrastructure is generally good, but a bit messy. Massive amounts of data to build things with.
- Good starting salary and benefits (but hard to get any raise)
- Decent work life balance, there was a work from home option in place even before covid.
cons:
- The culture of bureaucracy, time wasting and politicking here runs deep. Everything is made more complicated than it needs to be, and takes far too long.
- Good work is not rewarded here; it's all about the optics, and who you know, not what you know.
- Complex, hierarchical reporting structure with 0 communication between different business lines.  Swathes of people in middle/upper management that add no value. 
- Data science projects often fail due to poor management, even when the initial idea was good.
- No career progression plan available for data scientists

headline: Rigid guidelines
pros: Team lunch once a month
cons:
- The guidelines used to determine whether a customer's account activity is fraudulent were too rigid leading to extremely inaccurate results. The analytical methods used were very rudimentary, and did not uncover much insight from the data. The department felt more like a front to show they were tackling money laundering issues rather than actually dealing with money laundering issues. 
- Overtime was extremely common. 
- Monotonous work which was neither fun nor challenging.

headline: Mediocracy and Bureaucracy Everywhere
pros: 150 years of history and heritage.
cons: Mediocracy, politics, backstabbing, people managing up constantly being promoted despite lack of strong performance, skills or merits, is very widespread. There is a toxic work culture. As an example, everybody knows there is a "Lebanese mafia" in their Global Banking and Markets business, but nobody dares to do anything about it. Zero focus on customers whatsoever. All senior execs are entirely focused on maximizing their pay, playing politics, promoting those who manage up and punishing those who courageously speak up.

headline: Still far too many Ivory Towers
pros: Still has a very international culture, and has huge opportunities if people are empowered to make the changes required. Decent culture although for all the talk about doing the right thing, much of this remains warm air in many circles.
cons: Not one bank but 3 separate banks, operating in 4 different regions. Huge legacy of antiquated systems, and little appetite to really approach this. Very heavy top management layers, with major ivory tower syndrome. Bad news or messaging stays a middle management level. Go against that at ones own risk! Zero HR department, or rather zero assistance from HR, who make up a large % of staff, but have outsourced 98% of tasks either to HRdirect website, or to Centre of Excellence in India. If Aliens were to abduct 90% of the UK/Global HR function, the business would continue without realising they were gone. I wont comment on what the Alien's would make of them, but fair to say they may leave with a relatively poor opinion of the work ethics on planet earth.

headline: Good environment, not great for progression
pros:
-Relaxed atmosphere
-Growing team (intermediary mortgages)
-Everyone friendly 
-Considerate lower management 
-Great pension

The role specifically is pretty good, the jobs monotonous but thats as expected. It's generally a good atmosphere.
cons:
The biggest con for me is how the bank handles progression and talent. Theres very few opportunities for progression, especially for those starting out there careers (GCB 8-6). The bank fails to adequately invest in retention and personal development. Theres people in the team with real talent who have worked in the same entry-level role for 5 years+, or at best moved 'sidewards' to different but similar roles.

I'd highly recommend those starting out their careers, people driven to progress and wanting somewhere to develop a career, to look at other companies. 

On three separate occasions I've contacted someone in the talent/recruitment team to ask about a role advertised on the internal careers, just to have my email ignored. These are 'colleagues'... ignoring my emails where I'm simply inquiring about a role... that's how poor the 'talent' team is.

headline: Best employer I've worked for by far!
pros:
Positive work culture; great people to work with, management encourage you to work at your own pace (within reason) and really help help empower you to be at your best. Great deal of flexibility in terms of catering to your wishes regarding the pace you want to develop. I have felt my voice is always heard and I feel very valued in my team.

The Whiteley office is a very pleasant work environment, I do miss the premises a lot having not been there for nearly a year.
cons:
Salary structure and promotions follow quite a rigid formal process. The pay rises haven't been great recently but due to very understandable circumstances. 
IT issues take quite a length of time to resolve.

headline: Excellent career growth opportunities but unclear outlook of company
pros:
1. The learning curve is steep and there is a strong mentorship culture among seniors within internal audit.

2. It is possible to participate in audits with global teams and for seniors (usually for senior auditors and higher), there are global career opportunities within HSBC.

3. The management is respectful and the workplace is peaceful.

4. At least for juniors, the work-life balance is decent and the job is not too stressful.

5. The company cares about the health of its workers. During the COVID pandemic, the company has switched to a fully remote model and as of February 2021, there is still no plan for going back to the office.
cons:
1. The policies are complicated and some procedures are outright Byzantine, making life difficult. Also, internal tools are hard to use.

2. Outlook and strategic priorities of the company are unclear and upper management does not properly communicate its plans. On the local level, HSBC periodically considers exiting the Turkish market, e.g. in 2020. Globally, growth and profitability have suffered for a long time, resulting in massive restructuring plans and uncertainty. Also, there is a clear disconnect between local and global management.

3. Even though the learning curve is steep, the small size of the local audit team (~20 people) means opportunities for specialization are few. If you want to focus on a specific area, e.g. model risk or finance audits, that might be difficult. However, if you can join the global audit teams or if you prefer being a generalist, that is not an issue.

headline: Disorganised & Bureaucratic
pros:
-international/global/diverse
-people are pretty solid overall
-product offering and potential is staggering
-looks good on a cv
-work/life balance
-lots of holidays
-good pension
-tons of great problems to solve.
-I think Noel Quinn is solid, but he has some work cut out for him.
cons:
If you work in data and are good avoid HSBC. Leaving my prior job for HSBC was a massive career mistake. 90% of the leadership (GB3+) isn't technical, lacks creativity and has no vision. 

-From getting the official offer, onboarding to day-to-day it was the most disorganized, to the point of being unprofessional, company I've ever worked for or with. 

-After a year I found myself making less money after a massive cut to my bonus - with no explanation, with less control, with fewer resources, and in a less progressive business culture than prior roles. 

-My manager cared more about political land grabs and PR than building legitimate machine learning programs. Their focus is on not making waves, looking like they are building something despite being clueless, and or avoiding owning any decision at all cost. Standing out, even for good things, was a bad thing.

-There is nothing you can get at HSBC that you couldn't another F100 while making more money and being in a more professional environment.

-Everything was undisciplined, reactionary, and disorganized. Basic things like paying vendors , or decisions in general,  are typically 6-12 months overdue months late because of incompetence.

-Do not trust what they say about resources in the interview - there is no real  process. Budgets  are 100% dictated by "ExCos," who hear and repeat buzz terms like "agile," "transformation", "cloud" or "AI" understand none of it and allocate at random. 

- For the ambitious or innovative there are no professional development or mentoring opportunities. There is no reason to stay past 18-24 months. 100% of people with modern skills were miserable and looking to leave within six months shocked by how low the bar is. 

-Most executives are either ex MBB consultants or IM's that have been there or are going to be there 10-20 years. No one in between. I thought most of the IMs were solid - much more so than the consultants who were given leadership roles. It felt like they cared. But if you aren't one of the two, I can't recall upward mobility past GB3.  

-Never saw a person promoted for skill or originality, but executing, often I'll thought out, plans and not questioning the powers at be. Mind HSBC's stock and profits didn't drop 55% and 35% percent over the last two years because of good decision-making. They are in desperate need of creative and sharp thinking.

headline: Conservative organisation searching for a role in the new digital world
pros:
-	Depending on where you are in the organisation it can be great to be able to move around if you are younger and have the qualifications.
 -	Can pay well if your role is in demand.
-	The painful process Noel Quinn (CEO) has embarked upon to shed 35 k staff is going to shake up the bank and its capabilities which is welcome unless you're living it internally the negative impact is that there is incredible pressure to cover roles which are no longer recruited and people in some areas they doing long hours with no end in sight.
-	Female managers see more chances of promotion than previously but there are still large enclaves of male-dominated non-white sexist pockets in different areas. ( btw I am male )
cons:
-	Managers can be particularly arrogant but may have multiple faces.
-	Hard to move roles at some stages of your career, seniors closed about some people if they have formed a negative view.
-	I saw lots of people who are in the older generation 'locked' into their role and unable or unwilling to put their hand up for change as the result could be negative.
-	Some senior managers manage to stay in role for years without developing themselves or being able to be developed.
-	It started to become more autocratic in management style choosing to command and control. This probably depends on which area you work in.
- The chain of command can be so vague that your manager doesn't understand what you do and what your skill set is and hence development can be challenging.
-	Achieving band 3 middle management is an achievement but every 5 years they have a clear-out and more band 3's are removed at every cull.
-	The middle market is dominated by HSBC and it beats other banks hands down, the market is more lucrative generally that S&P 500 which has razor-thin margins, the negative side is that RMs typically handle huge portfolios of 80+ clients and do not get to know their customers and can be worked intensively.

headline: Terrible Management
pros:
Benefits Package is well thought out 
New office in Sheffield was nice and open
cons:
Lack of leadership and no clear understanding of what teams add to the overall organisation, more interested in bottom line and cutting jobs
Most managers in the organisation especially at GCB4/3 are pretty poor, they lack good interaction skills
Development opportunities are limited unless you kiss the ring. Can be a great worker, put in hours over your weekly requirement and never get mentioned or recognised for the work. Others will get pushed to senior roles within 6 months and then just leave for more money elsewhere. 
Training is pretty much non existent
Not a stable work environment, if you expect a long term job at this bank then you're in for a shock

headline: Lacks innovation and led by dinosaurs
pros: A huge company, lots of benefits e.g. healthcare, opportunities to move to other teams internally. Lots of nice people that make you want to come in to work everyday.
cons: Severe lack of diversity at senior levels. No innovation, a place where hard work and talent isn't recognised, they love bringing in new and inexperienced people and adding layers of hierarchy, instead of promoting young talented BAME people. Layers of bureaucracy make it impossible to deliver anything, and internal politics and constant restructures make it a difficult place to actually own and deliver good work.

headline: Too bureaucratic too political too unwilling to change
pros: Colleagues, International outreach, Location, Perks at work

For an organisation who claims they want to change and have too many change teams, there's practically no change with projects commissioned and funded, when eventually finishing, just being gone to the bin alongside the work of the various teams. Careers wise if you befriend senior management, irrespective of the quality of your work you will advance.

headline: Too slow, too low pay, comp and mgt mean good ones go & non-performers stay
pros: Great global presence and leadership in some banking categories, potential global work opportunities (not during pandemic or recent financial troubles, but...), global connections and perspective - Note that Career Opportunities will vary dramatically with your region. US, Canada...not so much especially now and in the foreseeable future.
cons: The company as a whole has good people and some good products, but its very siloed structure renders it stodgy, slow to respond, hierarchical, and its very, very poor upper-middle management talent is bordering on criminal in its low level of quality. There is rampant favoritism, low pay vs. competition and a 'socialist' bonus system (only a few get paid a lot, most - including blah performers and high performers) get a little bump, regardless of performance, year after year after year. Just enough to keep the good ones around until they find another place to go and the bad ones find a way to survive. Even a recent massive and unpublicized layoff in the US and elsewhere was a classic salary-cutting and ageism play...but still many, many lukewarm performers remain, albeit at low salaries probably higher than they deserve while many of those cut were higher paid for a reason.

headline: Too big for its own good.
pros: Big organisation with room to move, good benefits and good learning opportunities. Will give staff a global view of operations.
cons: Overly bureaucratic, slow moving, internal promotion is overly difficult without moving departments. Bulling behaviours are often tolerated and lots of staff that have been there for decades that add little to no value. You are just a number and will be pushed around according to need. Lack of female/ethnic minority senior leaders which also leads to homogenous and poor business decisions. Pay increases are minimal and bonuses vary widely across the organisation.

headline: Great opportunities, terrible culture
pros:
Variety of roles you can work in: the “lifers” - people who’ve only ever worked at HSBC or have worked there for many many years, tend to have had varied careers in different locations. 
Global scale: If you’re looking for scale and a truly global organisation- this is it! Remarkably global as you’ll most always work with teams in other markets. I start calls in Hong Kong in the morning, UK in the day and US by the end of the day
cons:
People & politics: some people are very very toxic in this organisation. Especially those that have worked there for years as they have the very old school culture and fear of the manager / seniors embedded in them. There’s a culture of empire building which binds a lot of people from doing the right thing. 

Red tape: The bureaucracy is incredible and unnecessary.  Yes it’s a highly regulated industry, however some decisions take too long to be made and not because of regulation, but because certain teams don’t want to spend budget or want to play politics. 

Waste: there are a lot of people in management roles, especially at grade 3 who do nothing and bring no value. Often times these are the ones that let it down for the rest, cause bottle necks and badly manage people. 

Prejudice: unchecked prejudice and too much control given to managers with no checks.

headline: Honest, fair and true of my experience
pros: - Pension and benefits are good
cons:
The Swansea ‘contact-centre’ is one of the most unwelcoming and toxic work environments I’ve ever experienced. 

From the get-go you are treated as just a number by management and ‘colleagues’ around you. 9 other people started the same time as myself and within the first three months 6 had resigned largely due to job dissatisfaction. The training group I joined were all herded on the telephones as quickly as possibly with abject and minimal training (3 days out of the 20 days training was spent covering a topic which is not relevant to the role). 

The training provided was by a third-party company and not HSBC, therefore, information that was being provided in training was out-of-date and not in line with current policy and procedure.

Myself and others had first-hand experiences of harassment and bullying from selective colleagues and managers. One particular incident I remember is a ‘senior’ manager trying to make an example of me in front of the office floor of 15/20 people. I cannot give the specific example because it will probably identify who I am , and I’m confident the managers will have a good-laugh about how they tried to belittle me . This example is just one of many within the Swansea ‘call-centre’ of management being pedantic about trivial issues instead of managing staff properly and providing a high level of customer service. 

After this particular incident I lost all respect for management within the ‘call-centre’ and immediately started looking for alternative employment. 

Conflicting information from employee to employee! Because the organisation is so large, it’s hard to have consistent messages communicated. I found that i’d come in one morning and one senior is telling you one thing and another manager another, which in a customer service role can lead to very irate and annoyed customers if you’re not providing accurate information.

Finally, I found the job to be repetitive and soul- destroying as you deal with 40/50 calls a day, the large majority of these customers are already irate before you speak to them because they’ve been waiting in a queue for 40-50 minutes (on a good day). 

This job could be for some people but not for myself, the ‘call-centre’ environment has a low ‘ceiling’ when it comes to progression and pay, the mortgage department was littered with employees who had been in the job for 10-15 years and were still earning £17,500, for people with ambition I would say the ‘call-centre’ is not for you.

headline: Good to work with for a short while
pros:
Good extras package e.g. health insurance, potentially good performance-based salary increases.
Quite transparent in terms of promotions etc.
Very transparent framework for determining employee performance and consequently determining bonuses.
If you are able to get a specialized management-grade role, there can be international opportunities for you throughout HSBC worldwide.
Very robust at risk management etc. Experience at HSBC, especially in a risk management role, can make you highly employable in good roles at other banks.
cons:
While theoretically committed to promoting work-life balance, in reality many positions have heavy workloads and the pro-wellbeing message tends to get lost at middle- and lower-management level.
Starting salaries are very low. Perhaps its better to start your career elsewhere and apply for an HSBC management role when you already have a competitive salary elsewhere.
Immensely bureaucratic and rigid, which can be frustrating.
Customer service is often not good, which as a customer-facing employee can be demotivating.

headline: Excellent people, nurturing culture, caught in geopolitical crosshairs
pros:
Very smart teammates, motivated and willing to work together. Pay is quite good. 
Alot of exposure working in a global Bank and opportunities to work overseas (pre covid) were numerous. My boss would step up for me when in trouble, at his own expense. That's rare in any organisation.
I would say such the team culture in my specific department is excellent and hard to match anywhere
cons:
Bogged by tensions between us and China. A serious issue affecting strategy and it is no longer within management control. 

Firm is also large to the extent of being bureaucratic but imagine this is there with all large firms

Alot of team reshuffling at the global level which eventually unwinds over years and is confusing for staff.

headline: Commercial Banking Graduate Programme
pros: Strong company culture, good work-life balance (dependent on team), friendly and inclusive culture, above average pay for a graduate scheme
cons:
I would like to add to the review left on 29 June 2020 for the Commercial Banking (CMB) Graduate Programme to reflect that the sentiment described was definitely not an isolated case - a lot of graduates had similar experiences.

Removing subjective judgments the CMB Graduate Scheme has been plagued by numerous problems - I would address two in this review. First, mismanagement. Across different cohorts graduates have been told at the very last minute of “sudden business changes” which required re-assignments from value-adding placements to basic call centre roles, and in at least two instances even a mandatory extension of at least six months to the 18-months programme graduates signed on to. What graduates signed on to was an 18-month national mobility situation, not what inevitability transpired as described. It was widely felt that there was complete disregard for any personal circumstances, where everyone was expected to accept this out-of-contract, unforeseen arrangement without protest (for any protest received admonishments for graduates being “ungrateful” and “entitled” and “having bad attitudes”), uproot themselves and resolve any logistical or financial issues at last-minute notice, with minimum to no support. 

Second, under-qualified graduate managers. While the above described could be explained as top-down instructions outside of the graduate team’s control being poorly executed by the graduate managers, the managers’ lack of CMB knowledge and lack of initiative to remedy that after years of being in the role was inexcusable. This was particularly problematic was because graduate placements were allocated by graduate managers, who screened placement applications. Graduates were told to write their applications in laymen terms, because if graduates included “technical banking terms”, the graduate managers would not be able to understand the application and would disregard those parts as irrelevant. This greatly affected the chances of graduates being placed in teams that best fit their skills and desired career paths. 

Numerous other issues could be raised with ample examples which would result in this review being unreadably long. I hope, however, that the detailed examples given in this review could give some context as to how the CMB graduate scheme was run. 

I could confirm here, however, that as stated in the 29 June 2020 review, favouritism and preferential treatments were existent, and that the high dropout rate of graduates particularly in the past year, as well as graduates taking time off due to the graduate programme compromising graduates’ mental health were true.

headline: Losing credibility and Incapable management
pros:
Employees Knowledge base expansion, 
Policy updates are quick and effective,
Leaves of 36 days
Recognition done on regular basis
cons:
Team leads/Manager needs to understand the process before she/he handles the particular team,
If you are not good with your manager you would be unemployed soon,

Micro management make you feel suffocated and reduces the productivity (Icats)

The process pressure is manageable but the management concern on ICATS is more on PMI than quality of the work

The employee bonus, pay is based on a underdeveloped monitoring tool ICATS

Egoistic and narcissistic personality have been selected to lead teams with ZERO knowledge on the teams and employees.

Main reason for not being satisfied is the pay does not equal your work or experience

Increment of 2% for an employee worked for more than 3 year better not give it.

Demotion of a manager with more than 14 years of service in the same organization to an associate without a valid or a logical reason is a disgrace on the decision maker and demotivating factor for a fresher to join and existing employees to work.

headline: Good brand bad politics at location
pros:
- Work life balance
- Good brand value
cons:
- Discrimination against outsiders
- More use of local language at office rather than English
- cannot trust management, will lie to you
- bad politics
- slow promotion, and promotions don't necessarily mean Big growth in salary
- you would expect it's a big company with lot of revenue but management will always cut corners and save money at your cost, your salary will not be corrected if it is below your market rate or if it is below the benchmark in your team. 
- Misleading job offers, they can change your team or your work or your shift after you join. They can change your position after you join. This is cheating as we join a company after careful consideration of other alternatives. They will use every loophole in the game to do that. Position and team can be inconsistent in your payslip just so that they don't have to give you salary correction.

If you are a non Bengali outsider, do not make the decision of joining this company. Try other cosmopolitan cities.

headline: Good Environment - Team dependant
pros:
1. Fixed shift and OT if you stretch(this depends on manager)
2. Friendly culture & team activities
3. Variable annual bonus based on performance
4. You get points on performance from team members by which you can purchase some items.
5. You get points to purchase latest books from Embassy store
6. Annually 34 leaves + 10 leaves(sick). But NO carry forward leaves.
7. Wfh allowed but depends on team and manager.
8. Good cab facility and night shift allowance is fixed
9. Few team use good technology and applications where as few use legacy software.
10. Activity with time capturing application in certain teams helps avoid overwork and maintain good productivity
cons:
1. Reviews and promotions are difficult and dependent on manager.
2. Work may get hectic at times and work-life balance may be hindered, although company prefers to have proper work-life balance for its employees.
3. Not much flexibility in terms of financial support for professional qualification like CFA, FRM etc.
4. Individual recognition and awards depends on manager's outlook and hence politics prevails.
5. Few incompetent people also follow the path of buttering and get success.
6. Salary not up to the mark, income inequality where freshers are paid more than lateral hires.
7. Canteen is okay, not up to the mark for Bangalore location.
8. Gym facility only in certain buildings as the company has multiple buildings at various locations in the same city.
9. No skip level meeting or HR interaction at all

headline: Some careers open more doors than others, but HSBC is about to end your whole career.
pros: 4000 HKD medical benefits included.
cons:
Very poor management inside the company.
Case: 
Restructuring every half a year, resulting in a very high turnover rate within the team.
The company infamously fired up to several hundred contract staff in a single day when HSBC escaped from the Money Laundering punishment.
Politics are everywhere within the office. 
Some teams would make your job way harder and would not cooperate at all, just because they hate the big boss on your team. 
This was particular true for me with a very hot-headed team head.

Seniors did not respect juniors and did not admit to their own wrong doings.
Case: 
Taught some investigation skills on Day 1 and pointed out the exact methods were wrong on Day 2. 
The manager also verbally abused me on my age and my working experience. They did so because HSBC officially cannot fire an employee unless they make a serious misbehavior or mistake, so they were trying to set me up.

Very poor HR.
Case: 
HR did not confirm my new position after I arrived the office for 2 months. 
I also waited for 1 month for my laptop delivery to literally start working. 
The HR eventually got fired.
Another HR even lured me into joining the exact same team again after I left HSBC, meaning they didn't even look at my previous files.

Discrimination inside the office exists.
A lot of teams consist of a full team of female employees, while other teams will try to have a male team head and several female managers on his command.
This left very little room for male starters to climb up the cooperate ladder.
Hard work came second and attraction came first.
Case: 
One time the female COO came by the team with a box of fruit cakes. 
She passed to one of my female colleagues and told her "Share among yourselves, but only for girls." 
I was so shocked that it happened in a company like HSBC which were told to have such noble values.

headline: Commercial Banking
pros: Good work/life balance, good company culture, inclusive and diverse, good amount of holiday, decent pay
cons:
The graduate programme are extremely incompetent and, in my opinion, should be almost entirely replaced. They care little or not at all about the well-being of the graduates, they’re not very nice people, they come from Retail Banking backgrounds so have no commercial ability to handle the CMB programme, and frankly, they’re terrible at their jobs. You cannot talk to them about a concern without worrying you’re jeopardising your career, they treat you like children and show zero respect to you. They have clear favourites and, if you’re not one of them, good luck getting a recommendation or decent rating from them. Would never recommended this graduate programme PURELY because of those who manage it. Which is a shame, because the leaders in the rest of the bank are pretty great.
Numerous graduates have dropped out of the programme due to the managers, many have left because of how the managers have handled the location/type of placements, and numerous have had to take time off because the programme has compromised their mental health.

cons: Performance of offerings compared to peers can often deter clients and IT/systems still going under a lot of development.

headline: If you have options do not work here
pros: There is flexible working which is great a brand new office also in Dubai with a nice eating area, new desks and equipment. Overall the leadership Is decent but The leadership direction changes too frequently.
cons:
I’m not sure if I have enough space but I will be very honest. The environment for new joiners is not great at all. The culture in HSBC is so thick it can cause newbies a feeling of alienation. 
You can work from home but with the strain of back to back meetings (there is a strong meeting culture which in my opinion is unproductive) it’s better to stay in the office.
Management is awful, juniors are promoted too early which shows through the calibre of the Individuals within the teams.
Highly competitive to detriment. Too many people scared  to loose their jobs and to be shown up so there is a culture of throwing  people under the bus, lying and blaming. I would say the worst is the management.

headline: "Diversity" is a PR stunt
pros:
Stability
Clear career paths
Potential to switch to other job posts
Many women in senior and management roles
cons:
Some colleagues are homophobic and one of them in my branch kept making vulgar sexual jokes
Diversity sections in the employee training sessions were skipped right over, probably because they think it's not important.
HR did a really bad job of dealing with my complaint. All they said to me is that the issue has been handled and due to privacy reasons, they can't tell me anything else. No apology, no empathy, no general gist of what they did or how the investigation went, or if they accepted my accusations, no feedback on my suggestions, no nothing. The ones handling my case were completely clueless about homophobia.
Bank tellers (not a sales role) were imposed sales quotas
Employees are highly expected to attend company events in their private time to "network" and "increase chances that you will be promoted in the future." The only criteria promotions should be based on is your ability at work, during working hours, not how much time you're willing to sacrifice to the company for no pay.

headline: 5 years at HSBC
pros: Huge organisation with many opportunities to challenge yourself and enhance your experience, knowledge and skillset if you’re proactive. Good flexible working culture and I managed to work with some great colleagues.
cons: Huge organisation = Frequent restructures. Challenging for employees to navigate especially if your role involves working with different business functions. Too much bureaucracy and politics involved which makes it difficult to get things done. Further complicated by poor decision making from management.

headline: HSBC Mortgage Sales department
pros: Work life balance, attractive remuneration
cons: For a sales person, the commission scheme is basically a bonus scheme with their current policy. There is no transparency as to how you get your commission, and a huge downfall of their policy is that your remuneration for your sales is at the discretion of your line manager. That means, if your manager does not like you and is not impartial, you will not be justly rewarded for your efforts.

headline: Good but could be better
pros:
Great Benefits - including subsidised top tier private health cover, some employee discounts at partner businesses, mild home-loan discounts and an internal recognition program with points and rewards
Generous Bonus - I have received anywhere from 3-25% of my annual as a bonus
People first culture - Several employee resource groups for employee activities, social clubs and a general care for staff
Flexible working - Formally negotiated flexible hours or ad hoc late starts/early finishes are ok. working from home is the norm
cons:
Terrible systems - Absolutely terrible systems and technology
Heaps of bureaucracy - everything is escalated and no-one takes ownership of problems
Lax working culture - there is an undercurrent of laziness which is generally accepted. Working hard gets you ahead but there is a lot of dead weight which you might find demotivating.
Apathy to problems - people are so tired of pointing out inefficiencies and issues that they just live with sub par systems, processes and technology.
The global scapegoat - everything wrong is a "global" or "regional" issue that "they" won't fix. Don't expect quick or decisive change.

headline: Biased hostile work environment
pros: Brand name, location of office
cons: HSBC is a place where talent is valued less than lineage. Diversity is for name sake as the brand managers who are responsible for diversity will indulge in discriminatory behaviour themselves. Hostile work environment where people will be nice towards you only if you are a ) permanent staff b) level equal to them or higher. Basic civility or niceness cannot be expected of the staff. Too hostile an environment. A manager even told me " Work doesn't matter here much, relations do". And this was when I had received appreciation emails from teams all over the world for my work. Well, If  a company doesn't value work when you are at the company to "work" in the first place, guess it is the wrong place to be !

headline: The blind leading the blind
pros: Great share-save scheme however i think i invested at a great time.
cons: At my time at hsbc i have felt the support for staff is disgraceful from management. Managers are trained to be slave masters as working there i heard “crack the whip” being used plenty of times. If you are unsure what to do managers will look down on you instead of help you. They never knew what was going on themselves. Managers will never listen to you especially in one to ones where its all about how im helping the managers look good. My time in branch muswell hill was run by a man who liked seeing His staff fail. He was pathetic. My manager at private bank and premier came across discriminating and like to try bully staff. My time at remediation dawson house was the worst with my manager not knowing what she was doing and was a Narcissist. There is a poor moral all over the company where people just care about themselves especially gcb4s and above. Im so glad to have left and found working for a smaller company was much better as we all support each-other and managers make quick changes when something is not working.

HSBC have an admirable vision and capable, intelligent employees in their employ, that’s for sure.
cons: Since the DPA, HSBC has had to make numerous changes, and oftentimes, that includes furloughing talent, often en masse. headline: Cold inhumane big corporate
pros: The salary is fairly competitive
cons: The culture is toxic especially in the equity markets division. The entire department (possibly the whole financial institution too) is staffed by back stabbing mercenaries who will not bat an eyelid if you died. Everyone was self centred and looking out only for themselves. Upper management imposed impossible targets on staff (think of what happened at Wells Fargo). Weekly emails were sent out comparing staff achievements, which included number of phone calls to clients, client meetings etc. The pressure was so intense to the point where analysts stopped doing proper research work and just focused on client entertainment.

cons:

3. You do not have a say if you're a junior.

headline: Worst Hiring Process
pros: Not Applicable .The cons sections is self explanatory
cons:
************This Company has never been my employer*********

Interview process lacks clarity since they hire u after multiple quality analysis or technical rounds.Then discuss with u as if it's an HR round where salary expectations and notice period gets discussed on.Then they say that they will inform you soon.The soon never comes.You are kept in dark for the results.On multiple follow ups they say that you are hired and can put papers if needed as we have blocked the requirement and you are selected anyway.Please don't put papers after this ,cos, they surprise u by calling one fine day saying that expected CTC and notice period is an issue suddenly.
Bonus points:
-Interviews scheduled on weekdays
-5 rounds of interview in one shot
-Technical panel won't be present inspite of having F2F scheduled by them resulting in multiple invites for F2F.
-Whilst you follow up after clearing all rounds of interview regarding updates, you'll be told that some sort of approvals are pending because they are planning to pay you high.
On the whole, even if u get in , better to not keep any hopes on this.

Thus the "Pros" section has got "Not Applicable" mentioned in my review.

headline: Ideal for people who don't like to work much.
pros:
Some teams/departments have great technology - RBWM Digital, GBM, etc.
Some managers are understanding, and easily give WFH.
Most colleagues are supportive and approachable, same goes for most managers.
Leave system (25-30 privilege and 10 sick, 10 consecutive mandatory) is one of best in industry.
cons:
Low focus on tech (bank-first, tech-company-later approach).
Little to no focus on agile and devops.
If you begin to work well, you'll get burdened with the work of entire projects on your own.
Cumbersome approach for approvals for anything tech-related - ranging from a a few days to a few weeks.
Senior management have categorically stated that they will never let go of 'heritage' tech like mainframes - which means most tech of HSBC will be stuck in the 60s.
Few aspects like strict dress code, bad cafeteria food and bad seating management on floors needs to be improved quickly.

headline: Jade Director
pros:
- Good Maternity Benefit (16 weeks)
- Good Medical Benefit including your spouse and kids
- Good Staff Mortgage loan . 0.8% interest rate and the loan can up to 120 of your monthly salary

- Retail Banking environment still embedded in traditional management, no VPN provided for RM, so home office policy is not efficient since no access to work.
- Take a long time to get your Work Phone or Work SIM card set up ..very hard to achieve your office email while you are out of office.
- BMs/ BSMs are micromanagement, eg check your sign in time, sign out time, lunch time, outreach time etc...
- RMs don't have a regular seat, most of the seats are mobile assignment
- if RMs need help for sales flow or SQ issue, hard to find a mentor for guidance and solution, all depends on different person opinions (which easily lead to SQ issue identify)
