headline: Run as fast as you can and don’t look back
pros: Starting salary, decent health benefits
cons:
Too many to list but here are some 
1. Wells Fargo pre law suit sales practices (super shady)
2. No work life balance, they’ll have you work 6 days a week without overtime pay and cut your hours or have you take longer lunches (which is illegal) they’ll have you manipulate your timesheet to not show overtime even when you work overtime 
3. The system is ancient, takes 2 hours to open up an account. Make you ask the customers questions that no other banks ask and a lot of customers feel like they’re being accused of wrong doing. Also, you have to use like 4-5 different applications to get one thing done
4. Bad leadership and definitely headed in the wrong direction 
5. No opportunity to grow and the turnover rate is so high they start you at a decent salary because they can’t keep employees. 
6. You never know when you will be laid off because the US operation is actually losing money and not bringing the company profits. They’ve shut down quiet few locations. 
7. They promise you $8k-12k in bonuses. Don’t fall for that it’s not true 

Finally, the laid a bunch of us off today after hiring us in November, that’s 4 months after being hired. They pulled us into the office and told us we have 90 days to find another job.

If that’s not enough for you to run away, then I wish you the best of luck!

headline: Great culture at HSBC
pros:
Excellent work life balance.
Great career prospects but you need to be proactive in this space. Speak up and let your manger know you are ambitious and use the HSBC tool available internally.
cons:
Such a big company that at times it is hard to work out which team you need to go to. 
It can take time to onboard new staff and to get full system access...don’t be put off by the length of time if takes. Once on-boarded fully you should have a more positive experience at the bank.

headline: Stay away unless you don't care about job security
pros: Global Brand? Maybe that's it
cons:
HSBC has been on a significant cost-cutting program for nearly 6 years now. It's the same old year after year cutting FTE around 150 per year and bring people back the following year because they cut too many people.

I was with HSBC for 15 years and finally left because the environment is absolutely disgusting.

Because of nonstop layoffs in the Vancouver office - everyone is throwing each other under the bus to try and save themselves. On top of that, the situation has become so dire that Management has started communicating to all managers that they need to artificially lower staff ratings to poor performers because they do not have any budget to continue laying off staff. This now creates a false image of staff being poor performers so they can be let go with just cause. This needs to be clearly communicated to all staff to ensure appropriate legal action is taken.

This year specifically management was pushing "Project Oak" which essentially made all staff hunt down individuals to cut. It's become a circus and almost sad as all management is throwing each other under the bus to try and save themselves.

I know of 5 individuals who have launched lawsuits directly with HSBC Bank Canada - and they have now produced lie after lie to try and hide their behavior.

My suggestion is for everyone to stay clear of this mess.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: HSBC's investment bank has a less intense and friendlier atmosphere than other IBs. The bank has a lot of excellent corporate relationships making it easier to do well. The package is attractive with lots of potential perks as well as pretty good money.
cons: HSBC IB is fairly unadventurous. It's easy to get stuck in a rut and even pigeonholed so that no matter what you do your find your career going nowhere. You won't get paid as much as in other IBs.

headline: Poor in almost every imaginable aspect (in Pune & Hyd in India)
pros:
Enough holidays in a year (~25)
Certain people at the top (such as Ravi) are very good
Chance to work on newer technology as bank is shifting from old to new ATM
Most developers are dedicated and talented, it's mainly the management that's terrible
cons:
Low salary and low perks compared to all its peers (DB, citi, barclays, etc.) If your friends work there you WILL feel bad when you compare.
Terrible management - mark my words, i cannot emphasize this point enough. I am not talking of the very senior management but team leads/project leads/etc. who report to the top brass, and especially the non technical employees like analysts teaching developers about tech.
Horrible HR, it was dreadful dealing with them whenever i had to.
On weekends the business bay building in Pune stinks of urine. The lifts are too slow and work on some crazy algorithm. I had to climb 9 floors of stairs almost everyday.
Compass mess is overpriced and low quality.
They don't take your complaints seriously until you resign after which they make big promises which are LIES, to keep me there at a critical time.
They might lie to you in their interviews, ensure to take down the benefits promised in writing especially if you are a fresher.
They treat Indians like a bunch of chumps, for example scheduling calls after 6pm in India or at night to suit their timings in UK.
Even if you are talented, you may be dumped in mainframe, production support, etc. There is no way to leave unless you finish 1 year and apply for IJP but that's 1 year of your life wasted and you cannot mention your experience outside

headline: Hostile culture due to lack of department funding
pros: Central location, paid training provided
cons: This department needs more funding. Staff is overworked and stressed out. Team leaders are overworked and not available for help due to high stress. Hostile environment to newcomers and experienced workers alike. Bereaved customers are often unhappy with the lack of sensitivity and hoops they have to jump through to settle their dead loved ones' accounts. Due to strict policies and high employee turnover, the office culture lacks empathy, and sensitivity despite the department's goals centering around compassion. More funding and an expansion in staff count could be beneficial. Also, poor communication with other HSBC departments leads to unnecessary red tape and preventable mistakes.

headline: Bad for me, may be ok for you
pros: Often pays more than other Buffalo area banks for same position. Opportunity to work remotely in some positions. Opportunities for international travel if you are into that. Good severance package when laid off.
cons: If you want to work here, do some research on the crimes they committed over the last twenty years. Maybe this will present an ethical conflict for you, and maybe it won't. While some individual managers are ok, the company is not. EVP-level and up treats employees like interchangeable parts.  The benefits package seems pretty good but it is really just what one should be able to expect from any employer -- PTO, health etc. Back when HSBC was still Marine Midland, it was a great place to work. Now there are a lot of people still there who are justifiably bitter over the company's decline. It's a huge transnational corporation and as such it lays people off routinely. There are people who have worked there for thirty years, but I doubt anyone starting this year will be around that long,

headline: Brilliant Experience for Technology Graduates
pros: Everyone I have met so far has offered their help and people are generally very happy to work here. I share in this view. The HR team are lovely, responsive, and always looking for ways to improve the experience for graduates. The social and work calendar over the first 2 months enabled all of the graduates to meet and build relationships with other graduates from all over the world, as well as senior stakeholders. Every step so far has also been an amazing learning experience, where I have been able to develop my technical capabilities while also building professional relationships.
cons: The onboarding is slow. A lot of software and hardware can take ages to receive access to. Certain training resources should have been made available earlier to allow a more fluid transition for later stages of training.

headline: HSBC Software Development India
pros:
Very good politics,
1. In a year you will get 10 conservative leaves which will be compulsory as a part of work life balance.
2. If you are relocating, then the policies are more than best. You will get 60k travel reimbursement, theey will manage your stay on Hotel for 15 days with allpwance of 1k per day(If you have family then 1k per head pee day for your spouse and 2 children ). They will provide the road tax for your vehicle. Also if you are taking a rented flat, company will provide the deposit money to you with no cost EMI.
3.Weekly one day work from home. 
4.if you are female and having a kid, you will get free daycare by HSBC also if ypu are not opting faycare facility then you will get 5k per month alllwance till 5 years.
cons:
1.work environment is not that cool, many people are here with 5 to 15 yrs of experience and they are very uncool in terms of behavior.
2.bell curve yearly rating process, in a team they need to find at least 10% people with no hike and incentive, they will take silly reasons for this category.
3. Employee firing rate is high.
4.Other teams manger will think that they own you as well and can start complaining to higher management.

headline: Fairly good place to work, depending upon the department
pros:
1. Adopts latest technologies much faster than other big corporates.
2. Good salary hikes, additional performance based bonus above CTC, good rewards and recognitions system.
3.  Allows employees to transfer to other departments, no Manager approval required, after 12 months working in one dept.
4. Plenty of  leave options. Mandatory 2 weeks of continuous leave per year.  Optional 6 months sabbatical after 5 years of continuous service.
5. Good learning options. Access to Safari, Coursera, LinkedIn Learning etc. Regularly holds hackathons and coding competitions with good prizes.
cons:
1. Visibility & opportunities varies from department to department. This is not linked with the performance of the dept in terms of profit provided to the company by that dept.
2.  Very limited travel opportunities. Few people travel multiple times, others are not given any chance.
3. Core functionalities are still running on old legacy systems, making integration with newer applications a nightmare. Very little effort put to modernise those systems. 
4. Terrible facilities in both Hyderabad and Pune offices. LCC Hyderabad campus has limited parking - only 4 days in a week, resulting in illegal parking on the narrow road to office. Inadequate lifts in Pune office. Poor and expensive food in canteens.  Management turns blind eye to these issues.

headline: Needs a complete Revamp of Recruitment!
pros: There are lots of good things about HSBC. It has a good culture and work life balance, good exposure to best practices and technologies. Compensation is as per industry standards.
cons: The Recruitment (or precisely, the recruiters!) is a nightmare here! The Recruitment team is so lethargic and the processes are such a mess! From a candidate's perspective, if there's an Opening to which the profile of the candidate is a 100% match, he will still be unsure if a recruiter actually gets to look at it. There are so many channels for putting the Open positions - through LinkedIn, Naukri, IIImJObs as well as Agencies, that even recruiters can't manage properly. From the companies side, it is always hard to find the right candidate, all thanks to recruitment team and process, and even if a candidate is found, the onboarding Process takes ages! In many cases, the candidate either gets another offer or ends up following with the recruiters for initiating the onboarding himself! All in all, there is no Morale check of potential joiners, salary negotiations are very stringent so much so that they even bargain for a mere 5%.

headline: A good place to shape your career
pros:
Lots of opportunity to move into and different business areas. 
Really good people working at the organisation (the vast majority).
Good benefits (other than salary) and culture is generally positive.

Sometimes work can go unrecognised. Some individuals are able to do very little and be rated the same as hard workers.

headline: Truly, the world's global Bank!
pros:
- limitless internal mobility opportunities in every major hub around the world.
- relaxed, flexible working culture to suit every kind of personal circumstances both for contractors and perm staff
- many learning opportunities to develop career
- non-contributory pension scheme
- good employee benefits
- nearly everyone I worked with takes pride in working for HSBC
- decent bonus
cons:
- although employee benefits are good, base salary can be better
- you can't really stand out due to the sheer size of the organisation
- in order to be classed as exceptional, you need to have luck for an opportunity to present itself as doing excellent in your project / assignment is simply doing what you're paid for

headline: The best job I've ever had: great culture, great people, interesting work; great place to work
pros:
- Great people, fun and competent - but experiences vary. My experience has been very positive

- Interesting work - you have a lot of opportunity to work independently to produce good work. The surveillance side of work is both interesting from a financial crime perspective and interesting to see the affairs some colleagues conduct on work communications.

- Global opportunities to take your career all over the world.

- Great culture that successfully delivers results and finishes things, without sacrificing humanity.

- Good management - very unpretentious; forward thinking and gets things done, meetings are not just talking shops. Good work is recognised, they are good at recognising good analysis over good presentation.

- Very flexible in accommodating employees' work patterns, John Flint's personal 'Healthiest Human System' campaign. 

- Fairly effective audit ensuring that outcomes are monitored and tested.
cons:
- Terrible IT systems, I've never seen anything as bad in anywhere else I've worked. There is no effective shared document platform which results in a fog of email chains and contributes my second point...

- Beyond siloed - departments often seem to be at war with each other.

- The organisation is so large and the systems (IT and org structure) so bad that there is not effective communication so experiences and approaches vary wildy.  One office will interpret a governance document completely differently from another and they will be so siloed that this will go on for years. Messages are not communicated effectively and the rumour mill is often weeks ahead of official announcements.

- Control of information is ineffective. Information barriers too often depend on your seniority rather than a genuine 'need to know'. This is either the cause of- or symptom of being so siloed.

- Poor pay relative to its competitors, benefits are standard for industry.

- Favoritism and deliberately opaque on pay and promotions. 

- Product, regulatory and analytical know-how is surprisingly poor, again below the standard at other organisations.

headline: Outdated Technology
pros:
Brand name, decent salary, flexible shifts(mostly).
Leave management is good.
cons:
Infrastructure in Business Bay, Pune is below par. Lack of parking spaces and also (believe it or not) lack of chairs on the floor.
Bureaucratic processes.

Lack of willingness to adopt cloud in some areas.
Working on outdated technologies.

People who have worked on outdated technologies continue to serve as Leads and seniors even on newer technologies. This doesnt make sense as they have no expertise on the new technology, yet they lead such projects purely on the basis of the 10 to 15 years they have spent in HSBC.

Most of the senior technical people here are ones who have spent more close to or more than 10 years here. And they are woefully unaware of how the technical world outside HSBC has evolved in the past couple of years.
Technologies in use outside HSBC for the past 3 years or so is considered the latest one here simply because they didnt know about it.

Spending more than a year here would erode whatever technical skills you have.

headline: Not bad, if you have a good boss it is probably even good
pros: Flexible working as we are encouraged to work from home once per week due to space issues. Nice colleagues, good facilities in the building (perhaps not the toilets and the sinks though), benefits and pension contribution are good. A lot of newish people in leadership roles in the function so change is coming, a bit slowly given the size of the organisation, most seem to be for the better. Opportunity to some career progression depending on your area but very limited in others.
cons: Process on process on process, constant changes to said processes and poor communication makes it a tiring and frustrating place to work and you don’t really need to think for yourself as there’s a process for everything. Constant focus on conduct agenda due to the DPA and more and more assessments and process to ensure it’s enforced and documented, this can make it feel like you are just a “process monkey” and don’t add any real value to your internal clients and stakeholders. Mediocre performance is not addressed and contractors and perm staff who aren’t performing are allowed to stay for far too long, causing the remaining team to feel frustrated. Management can definitely could toughen up. Technology changes are slow but coming and in fairness, they are trying to change. Overall, I’ve worked at worse places but the bar is quite low.

headline: Not enough room here to list the negatives
pros: Good salary compared with other financial institutions, work from home, decent vacation time, benefits strong but deteriorating rapidly. Good people working there, but that also is being deteriorated.
cons:
Huge influx of Indian employees under the pretense that those skills cannot be found in the USA. This is reprehensible behavior - but seriously, who would stick their neck out? Even writing this is a risk.
Promotion of buddies without credentials or peer respect. 
Layoffs of quality employees.
Overworked employees who are left after layoffs.
Senior executives constantly spewing spin and carefully crafted "truth".
Illegal activity leading to compliance requirements and penalties for which employees who had nothing to do with it are made to take training and adjust their behaviors while no mention is made of oversight of or penalties to those who were actually guilty.
No training provided for technical staff, no respect whatsoever for technical staff and their need to keep skills current or value them as a resource.  No symposia, conferences, expos etc attendance provided - except for the fat cats who don't use it anyway.
Adherence to the philosophy that paying a foreign employee less money for less time is cheaper than paying a USA employee a little more (and retaining them beyond a 3-year visa) who will do the same job in 1/3 of the time and retain a valuable knowledge base and skills that can be leveraged into future projects.  
I think I'm going to run out of space here.

headline: Good benefits, not enough recognition for part-timers despite the work load
pros:
- Full benefits for part-time employees
- Groups & organizations you can join
- Most if not all of the employees I have encountered are super friendly
- If you do make your quarterly goals, you can get a bonus.
- The branch hours aren't too bad & most branches are closed on Saturdays which allows you to have a life on the weekends
cons:
- There's no real recognition for part-time employees

- Hours: They start giving you hours if you need it, but as soon as they need to cut back hours, & they always do, you're the first one that gets the short end of the stick & tell you that if you want more hours you have to go to other branches.

- Sales/Referral goals most of the time seem unobtainable.

- If you don't make your quarterly goals, you feel that you're job is at stake, & that goes for both part-time & full-time employees.

- They recently got rid of tellers having the opportunity to become full-time or head tellers. In order for you to move up anywhere, they tell you that you MUST become a personal banker in order for you to move to any position, "there's no other way"

-You will do MORE than what is required of you & your role, again, without recognition.

- No promotion's (unless you bring it up yourself).

headline: Oh dear.....what a car crash company
pros:
Prestigious name (just about) - HSBC still remains one of the world's biggest and oldest financial institutions.

Pension - One of the strongest in the financial services sector.  'Lifer's in Back Office accrue huge pensions!

Salary - HSBC pays above market rate for the level of work performed.   A lot of roles in Head Office include back office processing by individuals on high salaries (and costly pension programs).
cons:
Chaotic - HSBC is still incredibly disjointed, with basic systems not working, PC's crashing and not even having functioning lifts and building passes (this was none other than Head Office!)

Culture - HSBC is still in the dark ages with how it operates.  There is a clear divide between Junior Management (G4) and those beneath within departments.  There are clear themes of nepotism which breeds only a shielded culture and no openness or willingness to admit fault.  

Competencies - Unfortunately, a lot of staff are not equipped to work within the sector.  Hires are usually based upon whom managers personally like as opposed to just capability based therefore staff are generally within their 40's as an average and not exactly dynamic & challenging.  This unfortunately maintains the same poor standard and people do not think, they just do.

Progression - forget about it.  Speak to any former employee and they will repeat that there is a glass ceiling; Junior/Middle Management look after their own and that's it therefore sadly progression just does not happen.  Performance reviews are designed to talk you down for fear of creating more work in having to recruit new people therefore it's no surprise to see back office analysts at the age of 39!

HSBC recognised my potential & expanded on it, which in turn aided my own personal & professional progression. For this, I am very appreciative.
cons: A downside to the above was that I would never have the benefits of permanent HSBC employees, as my contract was external (via a recruitment company; Reed Employment Agency); although I carried out the work of 'higher teams' (some of who I had even trained, to perform such roles, perfectly), and I shouldered much responsibility, I could never benefit the same, financially; I would always remain on much less wages.

headline: Work Life Balance is Great, Salary Might Not Be That Competitive
pros: Work life balance is great. You can take leaves as long as it's within the policy. If it is, it's almost a no questions asked approved leave. Most managers discourage overtime. If there are multiple hours of overtime rendered, management takes notice and works on it. Phones are allowed on the floor which is something different from other service centers. Sleeping quarters, gym, play area, karaoke rooms, and pantries are great.
cons: The salary might not be competitive anymore. I have heard some of my colleagues leaving the company for a better pay outside. The company needs to review it's compensation package. It might be great for people coming from outside. But if you are growing within the company, the increase is okay - but not competitive.

headline: It Really Depends on the Team You're With
pros:
- Supportive line and entity managers who are happy to give guidance and encouragement, which is especially valuable in navigating the more complicated sides of working in a bank
- Depending on if you're working with the right team and product owners, the freedom to start and pursue new initiatives to drive better customer experience
- A close-knit environment with lots of cross-functional opportunities, which allows for self-enrichment and learning more about what other colleagues are involved in
cons:
- A handful of people are only interested in engaging in office politics rather than producing actual work of value
- Expect approval processes to be drawn out (yes, even for getting a Chrome browser)

headline: Worst Experience!!
pros:
Work from home
No micro management.
Good for politicians, smart talkative , sales people, 
good for people who knows politics and have some domain or functional knowledge on banking and financial systems.
cons:
Worst env out here, No respect for employees skillset, they just need their work to be done. Dont go by their marketing terms on new technologies. ultimately you have to work on 10 years old legacy technology.over here only functional and domain knowledge matters. if you are equipped with cutting edge tech like Micro services , .NET core , Cloud , dev ops, data science , Machine learning etc then go home, there will be no respect for you. BUT you will be a superstar if you are equipped with domain or functional skillset.
No career growth, seriously, who will ask these old technology and skill set on the current job market.

They provide the worst facility, no parking for car after 9.30 Am , no parking for bike after 10 am. every morning you will end up on anxiety over parking.Cafeteria looks like a fish market in pune business bay and foods are super costly. they have over hiring and over firing based upon the project budget every year for which they have minimum desk allocation to the associates. you will end up sharing your desk or sitting on a populated area. you cant leave your personal belonging on your desk mistakenly also because  it will stolen and admin desk dont have any answers to it.lifts are over crowded, sometimes you have to wait for 15 minutes.and on the top of that your managers wants you to come office on time. trust me , you will be end up with a exhausted day with all these scenarios which will impact you family life.

headline: Soul Crushing
pros: * Good benefits (PTO, health insurance)
cons:
*understaffed department
*Micro-management 
*repetitive job - you will do the same thing over and over and over
*no Time dedicated to Career development
*Keep track of everything you do with a program called Icats that track when you go on break, how long you were gone for, the amount of phone calls you take, the amount of applications you complete and etc. 
*No raises only account for inflation, everyone gets the same raise
*assigned times to take your 15 minute breaks
*Will lie and say its not a call center job but it is
*extremely high turnover
*Low morale
*horrible managers that only care about numbers not the well being and happiness of their employees

headline: Little Support to Smaller Retail Branches
pros: Monday to Friday employment. Decent pension and benefits compared to other financial institutions
cons:
Too much micromanaging of the sales team.
Pay increases few and far between, even when annual review is Strong Performer or Role Model. Difficult to reach out to other departments as no phone numbers, only email and you have to know who to send email queries to. Insufficient training and if you end up with an external hire for a branch manager, they can be useless, even after a year and a half. I recently left because of the increased stress causing lack of work life balance - the branch manager should be able to open a bank account for a new client after almost 2 years in the role. The BM is my boss and should not be peppering me with questions or interrupting my overbooked day because she can't figure out how to hook up her webcam or can't navigate the new mutual fund system. Half the staff has left in under a year and 3 of us were directly related to poor branch management

headline: Low comp, conservative, ceiling reached
pros: Really hard to get fired. HR wouldn’t fire someone who recently committed a typically fireable offense, and said “you have to give them a second chance”
cons:
Low pay that is way below market. Variable comp lacks all other banks on the street. With low risk appetite, HSBC has 0 competitive advantage outside of being “global.” Weak product offering with poor clients who would never ask HSBC to lead on any important deals. 

Commercial banking (CMB) pay is very below market. Graduates start at $65k, whereas other grads in banks (think Citi, JPM, even DB) start at 85k 

Most first year analysts from outside hires get 70k, again below market. 

Bonuses in 2018 were 6% after HUGE cuts for no reason, despite the bank doing $20 billion in profits. Most banks on street pay more for back/middle office support in both fixed and variable compensation.

Promotions are hard to come by, usually don’t amount to much of a raise. GCB system is worthless

headline: TIME TO ABANDON SHIP - A shadow of its former glory and sadly sinking fast behind the scenes
pros:
1) A strong company brand.
2) Strong leadership in their Retail (RBWM) Network.
3) Little chance of being made redundant.
4) A wide choice of charity and fund raising events to join.
5) Good benefits.
6) Wide network for job opportunities.
7) Good training programs.
cons:
1) Low salaries and bonuses - Most jobs within HSBC offer just over 50% of what competitors offer.  The only few individuals you hear of having any decent salary (albeit still underpaid) are the external recruits.  Low salaries also regrettably prevent most employees from taking full benefit of the benefit schemes on offer. Bonuses are increasingly being stripped down to nothing even for those who perform well at their jobs. 
2) Culture of micromanagement - I could go on about this for hours but I have even seen first hand management follow employees to the toilet and stand by the sinks waiting for them to finish only to walk them back to their desk.
3) A culture of covering up issues - This by no means reflects the entirety of HSBC.  I have friends who are very happy in the departments they work in however there is increasingly a culture of mid and senior management covering issues up, including but not limited to, thieving (i.e. employees being caught stealing money from colleagues), discrimination (i.e. racial and sexual), sexual harassment (i.e. mid management groping intimate parts of junior colleagues without their permission), workplace misconduct (i.e. mid management coming in to work virtually every day stinking of alcohol, shooting off for a boozy lunch and never returning).  Reporting these issues to HR very rarely led to any action being taken. 
4) Overall poor working environment - You are contracted 09:00-17:00 in most jobs with a 1 hour lunch break.  With that said, in most jobs you are expected at your desk before at least 08:45 with your computer started up, if you are seen packing up even as early as 17:05 you are judged for it and there is no paid overtime.

headline: Universal Banker - fancy title but not so fancy job
pros:
Benefits are good 
You can tailor what kind of benefits you want but doing so means a certain percentage cut from your salary in order to have them. 

Laid back job because branches are not busy 

Management are nice as people.
cons:
Pushed to upsell so much in the London branch I work at. Management will literally tell you go to people at the cash machines and talk to them about credit cards. 

Management are actually down to earth people but get on your case not because they want to but because they have to. 

The systems HSBC use are so outdated it looks like windows 1998. They take forever to load and are constantly crashing it’s embarrassing in front of customers. 

Low salary compared to the same job elsewhere in other banks. 

You’ll be sorting out more compliance issues then actually opening accounts. 

It’s a very boring job you’ll find yourself standing around most of the time or fixing issues around your account openings. 

Progression is slow and if you rent out/ live out it’s hard to get by especially in London

Bad tactics used to sell things people don’t need such as credit cards and loans. 

People resign so quickly here. When I started people who were in my branch for about 6 months resigned as they said the job was boring and could not live off the pay.

pros: Good pay with work life balance
cons:
Of lately, they are doing mass hiring, they plan to onboard at least 4k people as per their HRs, as per them it is due to they wanted to remove their dependency on contractors, I was offered a really good pay, but the truth is they don't have work. Most of the work is third grade, that they want to hide behind domain knowledge. You will be just doing production support in most projects..

Also before joining I heard of their hire and fire policy, well it has been one month here and I can say it is very much true.. each year they are short of budget, each year their policies change, sometime they want contractors , sometime they want permanent..If a projects does not have budget, they will just fire you, they won't even consider moving you to another department, even when there is opening out there..HR is almost non existant here.. Technology is very outdated, at the time of recruiting, they tell about clouds, mongoDbs, block chain, etc but all these are just there marketing strategies..I have also heard they have this habit of removing the whole team for cost cutting, like in my project there is no testing team, same thing they plan to do with L1 support team, they want these tasks to be handled by dev teams, so that they can get away with support teams as well and reduce cost..

Moreover employees are almost treated as cattle, literally resources, there are no benefits apart from your salary. 

In short, join only if you really don't have a choice

headline: Not the worst but not the greatest
pros: The M&S Bank head office is at a lovely location, free parking and spacious offices. When starting there is a lot of team-building and training and throughout the time spent there was consistent training and up-skilling. Therefore, there was quite a lot of support and you are provided everything that you need to do your role. A lot of the skills I learnt in this job I have continued to implement in my role today. If you work hard and take on board all of the training and feedback you can get a lot out of the role in terms of personal growth. I worked within the Contact Centre so there was a lot of people in the office all working together. There were some people who were absolutely wonderful to work with.
cons: Due to the amount of people who work there it can be quite hard to be recognised. If you do work hard and get on with your work a lot of the time you can be overshadowed by the companies favourites. Career progression is very slow and when a role does come available there are a lot of people competing for one job. This means unfortunately people who have been there for a long time aren’t in the positions they deserve to be in. Again the favourites do usually step into these roles. Therefore, although there are a lot of people within the workplace it can seem quite small due to the way it’s managed and structure is set up. This is not to say all of the managers are like this, there are some who are fantastic, its unfortunate that others can let the structure down.

headline: Not a great experience right from recruitment to training and production.
pros: Mand_off or compulsory 2 week paid leave apart from your PL

Felt a sense of dictatorship right from recruitment to production. Managers are in their own world. No guidance or connect with the team. Too many donts and practically no freedom to make choices. Not the least, too much work load. Although the lunch break is one hour, you end up doing your followup work during that time so technically there is hardly any time to take a breather. headline: Group Finance & Risk  has serious problems
pros:
Pro’s :
-Allow working from home 
-Plenty of opportunities, vast technology and regulatory related development work ongoing
cons:
- serious racism issue across finance change. 95% of staff and contractors are white. The 5% of minorities that are hired are not supported , tend to get bullied and this has led to a culture of aggressive, ruthless behaviour from the handful of people from minority groups, that have made it into senior positions.

- very aggressive culture. If you are Asian , Black or Latino there is little chance of succeeding . There is a strong culture of racism particularly in global finance change . 

- white managers do not  support the minorities, despite them bring less than 5% of the department. They don’t enjoy coaching or encouraging staff from minority groups and don’t have any concept of the challenges those minorities face when it comes to voicing ideas, trying to get a plan in place to deliver on a project.  It is only possible to get any momentum from the wider teams when a white person is leading. 
- I have seen that many of the white management  did not go to university, but worked into senior positions after several years at the bank. They have serious issues with diversity and don’t even tend to speak to people from minority groups. They aren’t the most sophisticated or cultured. Leadership in the modern sense , is non existent.  They openly speak about votng UKIP and Brexit.

headline: Internship feeling
pros:
1. It was the first time for me to experience such a big international conference, and I saw the communication mode of business men and their hurried presence. The participants were mostly foreigners and Hong Kong people.

2. I found that my work efficiency was quite high. For the same workload, I was always one step ahead of others.

Rule out two future career paths: administration and human resources! I do not like this kind of work which is mainly based on human resources and supplemented by brain power. I feel that I have no sense of achievement. I am the nanny of business men and have been working for them.

4 good practice English, and in no matter and can not find the time to cherish the interests and hobbies, good good reading, reading more!

Nothing is still a word, cherish the time, enrich yourself!
cons:
If you can't do pipe training, undergraduate salary is too low, the rise is not half of the CPI.

High pressure, little promotion space

Overtime is really much, far more than 36 hours

headline: The Management from Top needs to change
pros: HSBC as  a brand is excellent. Its written policies, procedures, and the 3 principles, Open, Dependable and Connected are excellent on paper.
cons:
Promotes Bullying as the very top people only prefer their own colour to progress.
The culture still reminds you of the dark times where ethnic minorities are discriminated based on their origins. Politically promote issues of gender equal pay and then discriminate against equal pay. White colleagues get away doing less work with good pay but ethnic Minorities are pressured to work long hours with less pay. Line managers authorise expense for an unlimited and unjustified reason for a favourite such as a white colleague but would refer to incorrect procedures to delay or not authorise expense claim for a non white colleague.
HR is useless as they do not have the power to respond to any genuine concerns as all line managers and the top heads are colleagues and support each other.

mental harassment.

headline: Great people and team values bogged down by never-ending Organization Restructuring
pros:
- Great team camaraderie --- multicultured work environment, different festivities are celebrated.
- Inclusive policy from the top --- LGBT friendly (at least at the policy level).
- Managers do review monthly reviews to check in on team members performance and give advice and guidance where necessary.
- Performance based bonus and salary increment --- you perform well, you get the reward.
- Most teams allow flexi work hours arrangement when required.
cons:
- Still using outdated bell curve performance appraisal --- no matter how hardworking everyone is, someone WILL BE GETTING a bad appraisal.
- Because of this, managers forced to defend your team when necessary.
- Never-ending cost cutting exercise disguised as organizational restructure resulting in increasing offshoring works makes everyone demoralized.
- Used to give decent bonus and increment
- Most people expected to work extra hours regardless of role.

headline: Global Firm with Pluses and Minuses of a Large Company
pros: If you enjoy working in an international environment with the potential to move to another location, this is the place to be.  On-site gym used by many during working hours.  Flexible hours.  Ability to work from home 1-2 days per week.
cons: A lot of people in top positions don't seem to have a deep knowledge of the industry. There is a true lack of leadership which means that not everyone is marching to the same beat. No role models at the top. A lot of slackers get away with it and have been there their whole career. The way variable compenstation is calculated is completely intransparent.  You're just a number and replaceable anyway.  Hot-desking adds to an impersonal environment.  No contact to HR ever, except when things go wrong.

headline: Horrible place to work/bank
pros: Nice people in your team.
cons: Hsbc is very much a face fits culture, you can only develop your career if you're manager likes you regardless of how good you are at your job. Hsbc is supposedly "customer centric" but all they care about is sales and profits. Even though they say there are no targets, if you're not selling they pile on the pressure to sell sell sell and threaten you with no bonus, no pay rise, and unacceptable behaviours! Customers are unhappy, customer facing staff are unhappy, big bosses are earning big bonuses and do not care for their staff or customers, you are nothing but a number to them....horrible atmosphere to work in! Unsociable shifts, regimented breaks and no recognition for good old fashioned customer service. Systems dont work, procedures are not customer friendly and out of date and complaints are justified.

headline: Becoming a people focused organisation
pros: Good corporate culture, less cut throat than the American Banks - perhaps a little 'softer' when it comes to managing low performing staff which may not be positive. Self-sustaining and relatively risk adverse. I like the new CEO - seems like a genuine and intelligent guy.
cons: Very complex and bureaucratic. Reluctance to be truly transformational. Hopefully some of the investment over the next few years will send this change.

headline: Nice workplace for interns (if you aren't looking for technical stuff)
pros:
- Friendly and caring seniors
- Nice working environment, with a huge garden and a gym room as well as a common room with massage chairs, table football and snooker
- Staff benefits such as 30% off discount at Pacific Coffee and low-priced Ocean Park tickets
- 1 day of work-from-home option per week
- Shuttle bus arrangement for colleagues living in Shatin/Taiwai, Tsing Yi/Tsuen Wan,  Mongkok, Admiralty, etc.
cons:
- Colleagues are constantly worried about the possibility of being fired, thus not motivated to work
- Conflicts between teams (within a department / between departments) can be complicated, mostly because of ambiguous team responsibilities
- Long travelling time to office: Located in Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate, HSBC TKO Building is deep inside TKO, around 20-min walk distance from Lohas Park MTR station

headline: Bullying, Sexist, Covering-up behaviour and culture
pros: The pension contribution is higher than average.
cons:
I worked in PPI Complaints, Edinburgh. The behaviour and culture of the vast majority of the department staff was absolutely disgraceful and lacking in all integrity.

There was rampant bullying from a big group of complaints handlers who had worked for HSBC a long time and had moved into this department, 'to get the redundancy when PPI finishes.' These people singled out a few of the complaints handlers who they had arrogantly decided were 'weak.' They constantly loudly shouted out degrading insults and stereotypes on the office floor based on the appearance and personality of the victim, which created a very hostile work environment. If a complaint handler was quiet, the bullies would shout out that he had nothing to offer and was a drag on the place. If a complaint handler was slim/sporty in appearance, these people would shout that he was a horrible competitive person who is trying to be better than us. If a complaint handler was English like myself, these bullies constantly shouted out that he was coming in and doesn't know our how things work around here, even after I had been there a long time.

The worst thing that was shouted out on the office floor were the sexist comments. A group would target complaint handlers who they found attractive and shout out comments - often very positive - about their body/attractiveness. However, these comments were mixed with insults about that person's personality and even their appearance at the same time. So they thought they could have everything their own way with the person which is totally sexist. It's worth noting that men were just as often the target of this sexism as  women.

The majority of the managers were shockingly self-centred and self-serving in their behaviour. They, like the majority of the complaint handlers, lied and pretended that they did not know what was going on every day, whenever an incident of bullying was reported. This was part and parcel of the back-covering and lying culture of the company whereby people denied all knowledge of anything bad that happened, just in case it might put them out  in any way. The manager who the incident was reported to would make it clear that they thought they were too important and had too little time to do any people-management, despite the fact this was part of their description.

headline: Don't waste your time
pros:
Work life balance
Nice people - I made relationships here that I will keep after my time at HSBC
Decent pay
cons:
Unable to accelerate growth locally due to being dependent on both HK and UK to give their permission to move forward. To set the context, HSBC has the majority market share in both HK and UK,  but remains a challenger brand in Australia - the company does not give the local market the freedom to innovate at the pace that they are capable of.

Political culture - Management are unable to reconcile their differences and are too scared to step on each other's toes leading to a general stalemate with employees being unable to move their initiatives forward.

Disabling culture - most companies do everything in their power to enable their workforce. This company is the first that I have witnessed where managers from different teams actively block employees from trying to do whats best for the business.

Alpha mentality, leading to meetings with people talking over each other to get their point heard. While this isn't necessarily a negative con if things get done, I found that the conversations were generally deflecting or pushing back on almost all requests for assistance, without any tangible alternatives or solutions being brought to the table - meetings can go on for an hour, only to lead to no outcome or no actions.

Too many disengaged employees due to their lack of control to execute and deliver.

Decisions to hire people not made on merit. People are within technical roles that do not have a technical background, and people are in managerial roles without the ability to manage people/programs of work. There definitely seems to be a certain element of favoritism in the organisation.

Catfishing - multiple employees felt that they were lied to regarding role and remit. Instead of utilising these employees to the best of their ability, and developing and nurturing their skills or passions, they were forced to become glorified project managers.

headline: Redundancy procedure
pros: Learn all the tricks of operating a multi-regional / global organization.
cons: The redundancy procedure was as un-humane as one can imagine.   With decades of service in the organization and plausible appraisals, there has been no discussion whatsoever.  A lot of unconfirmed news hanging around, and on one morning, login to company intranet blocked, called by manager into a meeting room, handed the redundancy letter, access card confiscated, had 5 minutes to pack belongings and escorted down the main gate, never to be allowed entry again  It was as if I committed serious breach that required disciplinary action!  And never a chance to say farewell or celebrate the decades of efforts there.  What a humiliating experience, especially to end the decades long of service!

headline: One of the worst Employers out there
pros: Well as far as IT/software department Australia is concerned  nothing other than brand name.Please don't join this place if you have any other option.
cons:
This reviews is specific to IT department of HSBC Australia.Worked there for a year almost and that too because it was my first job in Australia.I would have given a negative rating if possible but unfortunately glassdoor  doesn't allow that.
It really difficult to put all the cons here  coz thats only what is there in the software development/IT division.
1)Huge disconnect between business and IT , business treats developers as slaves .
2)Filled with incompetent and helicopter Managers (these are people who hover above your head all time asking for updates and see what you are doing ie when you are coming in , what time you are going , how many breaks you are taking etc,
who have been with organisation for many years and don't know anything else other than   micromanaging.
3) Too much of open nepotism  and its openly celebrated.E.g if  someone who has a big mouth and a boot licker will easily get into good books of the Management or business .So if someone in the above  category gives an update in stand up days after days I don't know what i did yesterday , today i am not sure what  I am supposed to do it perfectly acceptable and no one questions but if you don't fall into that category where you would be ask to update what you did on a hour by hour basis, it happened to one of my friends there not with me.

headline: Slow moving global bank with good benefits
pros:
- Good benefits - vacation policy, 401k, health. Remote work is allowed but highly dependent on area and immediate management team 
- Global bank, deep pockets, very low risk of going out of business
- Diversified business model and some ability to transfer across business lines
- Have brought external talent to shake things up. Early to assess impact.
cons:
- Behind the curve on adoption of technology, at least on the Retail Banking side
- Highly matrix'ed organization slows decision making and limits delegated authority 
- Not a place for an entrepreneurially minded individual 
- Growth opportunity exists but upward mobility limited as the company struggles with improving cost efficiency, i.e, slower promotions to director, SVP and above levels. 
- Needs to do a much better job of identifying and promoting talent  - acquisition is much harder than retention

headline: Disorganized, but Some Great benefits
pros:
Time Off Program (TOP)  - A VP starts with 25 days off.  It increases every 5 or so years by a week too.

Working from Home/Remote - HSBC has great flexibility to work from home. 

They encourage changing roles to learn other areas of the bank.  Movements are not discouraged.
cons:
This place is chaos.  It's very hard to make important changes at an intuition this large. In addition, since the parent company is in London, many of the Key Risk Indicators and standards are based on UK standards at the global level and do not account even for the way more stringent US regulatory requirements.

If you stay here for a few years, you will be sure to be undervalued and underpaid.  The only way to make more money is to work somewhere else.  Pay increases are never substantial unless you move up a Global Band tier.  Lateral movements do not consider additional responsibility, hours, etc. and are treated the same, so there is no pay increase if you move to VP role to another VP role, regardless of any of the aforementioned factors.

Bureaucracy 

This place undervalues People. And gets away with it. It also rewards the people who come from external, often less experienced / knowledgeable but are valued more based on a flimsy interview process.

headline: Customer Care  Inbound Service Representative
pros: They are not a typical call center environment. We can bring our personal belongings into the production area. We can bring food and pantry on the production floor. We can bring cell phones. Company events that they encourage everyone to join and shuts downs the site. They call it "Best place to work." They provide 25 VL: including SL, EL, B-day Leaves and required to plot 10 core leaves from the 25 as they practice work-life balance and additional 7 leaves for SOLO Parents as mandated by law and may use it even if you are still a probationary employee. Annual Profit Sharing even for those who are not yet regular employees.
cons: Very low basic salary. A very complex account that does not compensate the salary. Cannot cover unlimited HMO dependents, employees need to pay HMO taxes including the first 2 dependents.

headline: High Expectations

headline: Decent Place to Work
pros: The office in Buffalo/Depew is very friendly - lots of people to learn from.  Many job roles give workers the flexibility to work from home at least 2 times a week, mking work life balance easy to manage.  Benefits are very good here - most employees are able to start off with at least 3 weeks of vacation to start.
cons: Upward movement appears to be somewhat difficult unless you switch departments.  Higher level openings are routinely filled by external candidates, and the system for raises appears to be backwards.  If you get a promotion, the max amount your pay can be increased is capped by a certain percentage, leaving people with a long tenure at the bank essentially screwed, pay wise.  Managers would rather pay an external candidate more than give internal candidates the same rate.  Everyone knows the only way to really increase your base rate is to leave and then eventually return.

I've had the best managers who inspire me and believe in me; they are also funding my professional qualifications and investing in my development.  I feel very proud to work at HSBC.

headline: HSBC Australia IT Department One of the worst out there
pros: No option to  give 0 or negative stars otherwise would have given negative stars.If you are in IT department of HSBC Australia no pros whatsoever, please do not join this department in HSBC Australia unless you  don't have any other option
cons:
IT management of HSBC Australia     treat software engineers or developers as slaves .
Too much micromanagement 
When recruiting they will say work from home and flexibility stuff but after you join will send emails stating everyone needs to be in ofc by 9 and can leave only after 5 , then will say you cant work from home.
Full of helicopter managers who will hover over your head all the time to see when you are taking break , what you are doing etc  but not the actual deliverables.
Technology used will be that used in the ages of Mughal emperors but Management will  expect to devs to deliver stuff that beat competition .
Too many managers  who don't have any work other than monitoring people ie checking who is going to toilet, who is taking a coffee break etc.
Opinion of people who don't even understand basics of software development is valued and heard
Partiality and nepotism to the core.

The only effort I saw towards a culture change was the video they showed upon intake.

headline: Too much on your desk but you're paid for it
pros:
International reach and size of business means that you can always move somewhere within the Bank to further your career.  Can develop a career and get some good experience here.  

Has the feel of a must smaller organization than it is (though still moves at the pace of a behemoth).

People that work here are generally nice and easy to get along with.  Good day to day atmosphere.  Compensation is reasonable.  Lots of Millennials and younger employees.  Strong sales environment. Lots of time and money spent on education.

Work life balance is good (if you can get over the amount of work that everyone is bogged down with).  Generally lots of opportunity for remote working and adjustments to schedules to manage family or other responsibilities.

Strong consistent sales people are well rewarded.
cons:
Way too much work to be done by the number of people on staff.  Everyone is overworked.  Don't expect to retire here.  If you make it to 50yrs old here keep your head down - your days are numbered.   

Managers are good sales people and not good managers.  Lack of coaching and guidance (in spite of the material amount of lip service spent on both).  Plan your own career.  Get in - get the experience - and get out.

If you're not a top sales person you won't last.  Nowhere to hide like in other large banks.

In general you are just a number here and will be treated as such.

headline: terrible management
pros: Money is ok, Pension is better, Location is ok.
cons:
Management operate in a clique and target individuals. I saw them mistreat and ignore someone who left in a sideways move.
Also saw them not only refuse a annual pay increase to someone who was highly skilled, whilst asking them to continue with profile raising tasks... this meant people new in the business were getting paid more than them.


Assessors for work highly subjective, 1 assessor will have a different viewpoint to another, meaning you can fail your monthly targets due to subjectivity and it is a hard battle to get their decision over turned even if you have a strong case.

Shares - wouldnt bother with them as when you leave there is a sting in the tail.

headline: HSBC Global Service Center India
pros:
Good working facilities within premises. 
Good for individuals able to negotiate a substantial pay-hike, and looking for limited career growth.
cons:
The GSC entity is structured to be a cost-arbitrage center, and this is reflected in the policies and work culture.  The roles are operational in nature, with creative and managerial aspects of a job being retained at onsite locations.
I would recommend that folks take up opportunities here only if you do not intend to aim at career growth, and are ok with a tenure based career progression. 
HR policies unfortunately do not address internal conflicts of interest between teams and individuals. Prospective employees should expect to work within the constraints of redundant HR policies (esp. older employees and GSC senior management being driven by personal job retention).

headline: Good and Bad but not wholly Ugly

cons:
*Getting feedback progressed is difficult
*Long hours APPALLING pay - Boast bonuses but these are up to managers discretion and in first year you will rarely achieve the full bonus
*Call centre negatives
*Con you out of incentives offer rewards but give every excuse not to give you any extra money you are owed
*Target driven but pretending not to be. Say to focus on giving good service but will hammer on at you about length of calls and time on phones to the extent where lots of people will give poor service to get sales up (but HSBC won't refer to this as sales) and give poor service resulting in lack of first call resolution which they then panic about as well - it's a cycle they don't seem to be willing to break.

A lot of silos, nobody wants to do anything and those that do are dumped on and get written up.  If the manager likes you regardless if you are incompetent you keep your job. R U N.... don’t walk away from here

headline: Good long term employer spoiled by business practices
pros:
People tend to stay a long time here which shows that if you fit in and get on you can stay as long as you want (assuming your department isn't cut).
Lots of oppertunity to move within the organisation.
Consistently profitable, meaning I got a bonus every year.
Lots of working from home options in certain locations
cons:
Forced bell curve assessments meaning that your end of year rating can be adversely affected if in high performing area or have weak management who won't fight for you.
Constant negative press for various infractions.  This directly led to me leaving.
Pay tends to be lower than competitors.
Per the pros there are lots of people who have stuck around for a long time.  Some teams have lots of dead wood or are very stuck in their ways.

headline: AML Compliance
pros: Having gone through some pain (DPA, fines, etc.) AML compliance resources are better than many similar banks.
cons: The AML Compliance at HSBC space grew very rapidly circa early 2010s, meaning that, in some cases,  existing employees with extremely limited skill sets were promoted (in some cases several times)  into management positions out of necessity.  As I witness first-hand, the single goal of these chronically under qualified employees then became keeping up the charade that they had the requisite skill set to handle these management roles.  The charade often included over reliance on more capable, more junior management and staff as well as throwing other staff "under the bus" in order to save their skin.  Suffice to say it created a toxic environment where I had zero trust or confidence in many in management.

headline: Run Like a Government Agency
pros: Pay; Paid Time Off; Holidays
cons:
I worked in Compliance in the US; my comments are related to that Dept. This is a big organization and that comes with it's own issues, but I have worked at a number of big banks that did not have these problems and to the degree HSBC Compliance (in the US) does. 

Here are some quick hits: 
• "Tone at the top" is lacking coherent strategy, planning and execution. This causes (1) management to run from one fire to the next; and (2) everyone to confuse activity for achievement
• Compliance is fundamentally unaware or out of touch with the line of businesses they support.  
• Technology/Data Integrity is poor. There is no attention to detail, no questioning of data integrity, causing people to accept what is put in front of them. 
 
As a result, work product is relatively poor and key deadlines are missed. In order to fix it, management hires more people to do the same tasks (thus no real value is being added) - much like govt agencies often do. Consequently, they rely HEAVILY on contractors and junior level personnel to complete all tasks. As you can imagine, this causes contractors and jr. level people to quit more often.

headline: Limited growth
pros:
1. Flexible with lunch hours
2. A lot of team bonding events
cons:
1. Open to feedback - But turn a deaf ear when staff really confides with boss
2. They're quick to blame you for mistakes, but rarely express gratitude when you succeed
3. No recognition for hardwork but rather how you bootlick your boss (Common scene: buying coffee and tea for boss everyday)
4. No intention to retain good workers but insist on keeping workers just because they have been with the bank for long. 
5. Interviewing process not consistent throughout the bank. 
6. HR leaves everything to business/ line manager to handle hiring process/ complaints. No involvement from HR when there is a need. Not sure what have they been doing. 
7. A lot of unnecessary roles with overlapping responsibilities.

headline: FCC Audit
pros:
Great chance to learn about the regulatory environment and the global standards initiative
The environment in audit (outside FCC) is very good and is the environment within HSBC in general.
cons: FCC Audit has a very high attrition rate. This is mainly down to the management of the team. The environment is toxic and your voice is not heard, so most people speak with their feet. Unfortunately no one will point out the real reason for leaving (not wanting to burn bridges) so there are no lessons learned.

headline: Large organisation with a very flat management structure.  Hard to get promoted
pros:
The people!  It is a very diverse, multicultural and multinational environment.  You do most of your interaction via video and audio conferences (at least in IT) and you often have no idea which city some of the people on calls are in - could be India, US, Switzerland, China, you name it.  

You need to grow your network and get your name known for good positive work.  This will help you get good feedback and increase your performance review. 

People listen to anyone with good, strong and sound ideas.  Given the size of the organisation, not a lot of emphasis is placed on seniority, and you can quite happily engage with people several bands above and below you.  Just learn to treat everyone with dignity and respect, be brilliant at what you do, and you can make a name for yourself!
cons:
You are not likely to get promoted unless you are very junior.  The career bands are very protected and you have to be exceptional to get moved from GCB5 to 4, and a god to move from a GCB4 - 3!

Bonuses and pay remuneration of late have been quite suppressed, especially if you are a 40% tax payer already.  I had no pay rise for 3 years running with a "strong" rating.   If you are an average employee (70% of the population), you will get a "strong" rating.  "Strong" is just average - thats it.  No matter how clever you are or how hard you work, it is very hard to get recognised as "top", unless you are well connected and spend more time influencing than working.  I have found this quite unfair, as the people recognised are generally the loudest rather than the best.

With interest rates already going up a quarter point and set to rise again, the remuneration and bonus situation could change.

headline: Mid-Corporate Banking Overview
pros:
HSBC US has the following attributes:

-Brand.
-Global Connectivity.
-People/Peers.
cons:
-Complicated and slow delivery of credit, cash management and other bank products to existing and prospective clients.
-Convoluted Client/Prospect Onboarding Process.
-Management (a lot of managers don't have the understanding, skillset or experience to be in their roles).
-Production Focus  and Framework changes every 3-6 months.
-Antiquated and outdated systems in every aspect.
-Annual Reductions in Workforce, even if you are performing and doing the right thing).
-Compensation (don't expect annual increases and/or bonuses).
-KYC/CDD Nightmares
-Lingering Deferred Prosecution Agreement (The DPA)
-Diversity-other than white women in Sr. Leadership/Management, there are very few people of "color" in CMB or Mid-Corporate Banking.

headline: Some Good, Some Bad. HSBC is a Good Place to Work.
pros: I was with HSBC nearly 16 years. The pay was good and so were the benefits. There was life work balance and the work schedule was flexible.  Ample paid time off and was available. The company was solid and I am proud to be an HSBC alumni.
cons: I worked in the subprime mortgage area that HSBC bought from Household. HSBC did not want to service these loans and once the market rebounded sufficiently from the crash in 2008, HSBC began selling off the portfolio of loans. That resulted in my lay off this past May.  The site where I worked will be closed, if not already.

headline: Bad experiences here,  bad colleagues here.
pros: Nothing,  reasonable salary and good benefit here,  close to market rate.
cons: Bad culture,  unwilling to cooperate with others,  no reaction for tasks approval,  long working hours.

headline: CML Analyst
pros:
- Good natured people
- excellent work life balance
- lots of time off 
- good severance package
- full time employees have a team of consultants and offshore counterparts with minimal work for themselves 
-Hsbc pays its employees well 
- good 401k
- the place is full of oppportunities for those who seek.
cons:
- It’s a job, not a career. 
- Most people lack ambition, they are there for the years of service they have with HSBC.
- Most people have fancy and senior titles ( Head of.. Chief..)and very few people to do the actual work. 
- the non fancy title employees are fairly well engaged in private work while working remotely  and have several consultants and offshore teams to do their work. 
- In the name of flexibility many employees abuse the remote working facilities. 
- Limited budgets every year, lots of job cuts proposed. No job security.
- excessive offshoring
- very expensive healthcare plans.
- projects are slow to execute

headline: Sinking-ship bank as they shooting their last standing employees
pros:
1) Big brand
2) Wide array of business and streams for specific roles or career development
3) good salary if you have skill and negotiate
cons:
1) shoots itself on leg as reducing headcount at sametime freezing backfills/hiring every Jul/Aug is the worst thing senior leaders do each year. "Dear SLT please note this, you went nowhere in past and won't in future with same strategy. Cut big sharks not small fishes helping your bank run".
2) "your boss is your God", no skip level, if you try, then you a devil and to be kept away for rest of your life. The funny part is you escalate on your manager to HR or skip level or CEO it comes to decision in hands of your manager. Isn't it right! 
3) move within run the bank business, don't go stagnant,  it helps two ways- SLT looks at you like you vastly experienced even if you hibernated during your stint. And stay 20+ years to be contestant of CEO, being a veteran is all it matters.
4 ) Rules are for the followers, remember, boss's slave? - no rules apply, nothing, zilch

headline: Objective view
pros:
401k match
Pay is OK.  It's not competitive but it's not the worst
Great colleagues
I can't think of anything else.
cons:
Hours and responsibilities have increased greatly for retail banking and wealth management division without any increase in pay or even a thank you.

The core problem with the bank is that they are behind in times in terms of technology and strategy.
Another problem is that the firm is extremely top heavy.  We have so many managers on top of managers that layers are 10 fold than what it used to be.

We were in a meeting and our head was saying our revenue is pale in comparison to our spending.  So what do they do? Cut tellers who are making 14-15 dollars/hour.  All I've thought about was why not trim the fat up top and create more transparency and save 100s of thousands of dollars? That's because layers are safer for the guys on top to protect their position.

From my understanding the heads run the bank by a spreadsheet.  It's similar to Marxist theory.  Works on paper but doesn't work in real life.  

The branches are thirsty for resources and now the hours have increased.  So now we have increased hours with less resources, which leads to poor customer service.

New tech has led to even longer hours because there's no alpha or beta testing and they just roll it out.  

I really hope the top management gets their heads together and think things through before making any big changes like this.

headline: Wasted three years.
pros:

Most of the staff are young, so will make friends etc. Some staff been with the bank 10 plus years so a lot of knowledge and help around
cons: Salary is diabolical for what you do. Managers are unhelpful, rude and can just be nasty. No compromise with hours when your life takes unexpected turns. out of roughly 25 managers i had, 2 were nice. the rest were horrible. most staff cry everyday because of how horrible it is.  pretend to love customers but just want you to hit target. you are measured against all peers in the country on how well your targets are. Working 7 saturdays 1 off, back in for 7 again. no work life balance.rather than giving you bonuses they give you one extra day off per year. horrible company, wasted 3years.

headline: Career Supertanker
pros:
Great opportunities to learn, grow and progress. There is generally support to broaden your career and expand international experience -- but it takes a lot of hard work and sacrifice to realise it.

When HSBC finally decides to do something, they do it.
cons:
There's a strong "we do it ourself" culture at HSBC. This is sometimes positive, but often turns projects into expensive elongated affairs that seldom come to conclusion when they need to.

There is a significant tension in the corporate ranks between "global" and "local", and a less tense but ever-present UK/Hong Kong leadership tension.

It it's a bureaucratic place, steeped in traditions, held back but the scar tissue of multiple acquisitions and divestments. Insiders often suggest hay HSBC means How Simple Became Complicated.

headline: Too many jobs-worths
pros:
Meet some great people, 
can be fun if working in a branch with fun people.
have met colleagues that I am glad to have met and will know them for years to come.
training is good
Hard work is recognised and appreciated
cons:
Too many jobs-worth's who are upset with their lives/careers and so they will do anything to discredit someone who is young, intelligent and doing well. They will act nice to your face and then  stab you in the back. 

Nonsensical and ambiguous rules concerning employee behavior .

Managers will pick and choose who they like. Those that are favoured will be allowed to misbehave  without consequence.

You can get comfortable because the job is easy and you enjoy the atmosphere and time spent with colleagues and therefore you will not be as motivated to move on in your career

They will move you to another branch whenever they like without taking your feelings into consideration. You are just a number to them: disposable; replaceable .

Pay and bonuses are awful

headline: Read before you join
pros:
-Facilities (Infrastructure, Affordable bus services, Free cab services for support employees)
-Bonus is additional of CTC
-Idle for people who doesn't like to work much
-Core leave (you can take mandatory minimum 10 leaves together in a year, and no one from HSBC would contact you.)
-Events(Code Camp, Carnival, Annual functions, Train for Green)
-Great departments in respect to technology and salary are GBM, GPB and CMB
cons:
-Old technologies(Few departments are still using Java 1.4)
-Currently HSBC is not at its best. To compensate the fine, HSBC is going through cost cutting processes and downsizing.
-MAPS software which mandates employee to work on development software for 8 hrs/day.
-Clarity(Billing software), which has got more hectic. Its important to get clarity of that task before hand, to get billed.
-Senior employees which are in HSBC, in same department, now consider HSBC as their home.
-Politics
-Your skillsets will degrade with time.
-Contractors, Ratio of contractors:HSBC employee is 80%:20%
-HSBC Website(Its down every alternate weekends blocking transactions)
-Not so good departments in respect to technology and salary are ADM Digital and S&D(avoid them).

headline: Cronyism is rife and commonly practiced
pros: Overall an interesting company but it is a shame they have so many bad people working in management roles where cronyism is rife and common practice.
cons:
Cronyism is rife and commonly practiced.  There is a common pattern of managers hiring friends and colleagues into roles for which are not best qualified and do not deserve.  They secure the role because they are friends with the recruitment manager.  In particular a pattern of hires from a renowned failed British bank is lowering the standards.  I was forced out of my role after a short time to make way for one such hire.

In house resident temp recruiter Resource Solutions is extremely poor.  They churn out countless jobs but NEVER response to applications.

headline: V.P. Premier Relationship Manager
pros: The company has a good work life balance in regards to the hrs because they close earlier than other retail banks. They tend to close at 4PM for the public or 5PM. That's it!
cons: Where do I start, the company is using software from the 1980s based on DOS, you have over 4 passwords to sign in 4 different systems to do your job. Then you have to use a CRM software that is just an excuse to take time away from your work. Since you are REQUIRED to input your activities in order to demonstrate that you are "working" your book. This is a joke because it's used to justify your quarterly payout regardless of you exceeding your goals! Then you have Management that is so out of touch and also very much have no idea what things you need to complete and do your job. It's a disgrace that a company of this size, at least in the NY area, treats its employees like "disposable" rags with no regard to your career or how to improve your job. And NO, this is NOT from a disgruntled employee, this are facts of daily life in RBWM at HSBC. As an employee of HSBC you ARE NOT GIVEN the tools to do your job. All of the forms have to be completed by hand which increases the likelihood of you making a mistake which then increases your job insecurity. Management has no regards, nor do they care, on making sure that you decrease mistakes as these issues are not resolved.  Management has no liability and you as an employee have ALL the liability and risk of risking your reputation. My advise is stay AWAY from HSBC, it's not worth it.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: I worked for HSBS Mortgage Services and really loved it! For being a worldwide global bank they did a good job treating their employees well. HSBC trained and gave us opportunities to work in several different departments, if you had a  willingness to learn. We were given great base pay plus monthly incentive bonuses that rewarded individuals and teams for our quality of work and production, plus excellent company benefits that included: choice of 3 medical and dental plans, 401K with company match (up to 10%-I put in 4% they put 6%), generous amount of TOP time and holiday pay, HSA with $1k annual company contribution, FSA, short and long term disability pay, discounts though corporate perks website, company paid life insurance equal to your previous year's annual pay. Additional perks also included: casual dress code, flex time, team building events, monthly dept meetings for updates that also included playing games, free lunches, dept contests, employee anniversary luncheons, in-house cafeteria, in-house gym, side by side training but the best part was I made LIFE-LONG FRIENDS!
cons: Unfortunately, corporate decision was made to close the Brandon, FL facility and no longer continue servicing loans in the US, otherwise I never would have left the company!However, sufficient notice and the generous severance package that was offered made leaving easier though.
