headline: Interesting, varied and very multicultural environment but huge bureaucracy and office politics are rife.
pros: The footprint of the firm is huge in terms of market segment, geography, products and services so a fabulous place to learn your trade as an international banker.  If you can maintain your momentum through the ranks then a varied and interesting career can develop into senior management.
cons: Lines of communication are stretched and confused.  The amount of bureaucracy and waste is huge.  The business is prone to drift, stifled by unimaginative "safe" middle managers prone to shuffle reporting lines while maintaining the status quo.  The performance related pay model is broken with disproportionate pay and bonuses awarded to a minority of staff for mediocre or marginal (subjective) achievements at the expense of team performance.  Hence, what happens on a day to day basis in the front line often fails to match the laudably positive and dynamic "vision" statements set out by senior executives.  This can lead to frustration on a number of levels if you are the type of person who likes to make a difference and achieve tangible improvements in terms of profits, costs, service quality, etc. as part of an effective "team".

headline: HSBC , Kolkata
pros: Initial days (HSBC Kolkata ) were really good with good work environment & culture. Truly World class. Learnt a lot about Management from experienced Seniors.
cons: Gradually the work culture deteriorated and made way to a lot of dirty politics, unethical hiring & firing. Good People started quitting out of disgust. Thus HSBC Kolkata is no longer the best place to work. Especially in the last Dept that I worked with was the most horrendous in terms of Management, Work Culture, Work life balance, and in living upto the Brand name.

headline: Great Work-Life Balance
pros:
+ Depending on your team you can choose your hours and work remotely. 
+ Sicks days, Study Days and Holidays are all bundled so if you don't get sick often or need to study you get a lot of holidays.
+ Free banking, discounted loans, stock trades, currency exchange and mortgages. discounted mortgages makes a big difference. Banking perks for an IT job is quite nice.
+ Employee Stock savings plan
+ RRSP matching with limit
+ Flexible health benefits, given credits to use for 100% if you don't need much or you can use them buy 30%/70%/90% coverage plans with it.
+ Beautiful building, small gym and amenities
+ Work remotely from home or very remotely from an office in another country
+ Huge Yearly Cash Bonuses for top performers, you get what you put in. Huge as in from below average IT pay to above average IT pay.
+ Global and Diverse leading very interesting work, different rules in different countries (also a con)
+ Huge company can find almost any type of role meaning lots of opportunities, just get chummy with the right folk
cons:
- Lots of senior management changes and direction changes
- Need to be self driven as direction isn't always there
- Big and Slow, can't move without stepping on someone's toes
- Bureaucracy!
- The base pay is better than most business jobs but worse than IT jobs. Which is ok because the work isn't like most iT firms, it's mixed between IT and Business. 
- Age group average is high
- Coworkers lack passion and a tad resistant to change. Some even make you wonder why they still have their jobs.
- Global and Diverse leading very interesting work, too many rules in too many different countries!

headline: Very little actually gets done
pros: Relatively good job stability, pay, and benefits. Was a good place to work years ago.
cons: The company is ridiculously bureaucratic.  People say they are busy, but most of what is happening is meeting after meeting with very little or no action.  The idea that HSBC can implement systems on a global scale and have decision making for 80+ countries in a few people's hands has created a culture that is slow to move, blames others, and is hyper-political.  It is a frustrating place to work if you want to learn and have a sense of accomplishment.

headline: if you have other choice do not go there
pros: great medical, dental, vision and 401 (k), especially 401 K, you give 4% they match with 6 %, making total of 10 % of your income to retirement while you only pay 4%
cons: mean, unprofessional senior management in mortgage department.

headline: Premier bank

headline: Is BIG always better ?

headline: Watch out and avoid at all cost
pros: Good Heath package and attempt to have a modern view point
cons: Where to begin... This is a company where careers go to die.  3 realignment changes in the past 3 years.  If you have ever been through 1 alignment change imagine 3 in 2 years.  3 comp plan changes and direction in just as much time.  Layoff round after layoff.  Sad thing really... It's such a simple business contempt yet they are completely lost in the weeds. STAY AWAY.

Nice people

It is crazy that this company makes money... They have no clear direction and think everything should be standardize as a global process that never happens. Don't waste your time with this company.  They will close North America operations in the near future.

headline: Perhaps not the best place for an ambitious person to start out
pros: Good work - life balance and the culture wasn't excessively demanding (or at least no more so than you would expect at a 2nd tier investment bank). They were also good about getting you training when you asked for it, but you had to be the one actively seeking out opportunities for development.
cons: The organisation was very slow at adapting to change and not very innovative. It felt like a place you come to retire rather than to start your career. Also didn't spend too much time/resources in encouraging employees' personal and professional development.

headline: good chilled fun easy helpful

headline: Good place if you want a stable job of moderate salary which never give you surprise

headline: Requires revamping to stay competitive

Operations and job allocation well streamlined at junior level.
Opportunity to work with diverse cultures and people
Decent salary and benefits
cons:
Lack of strategic direction and alignment at senior level
Excessively aggressive culture that eroded team spirit, creativity, communication and ethical values.
Senior managers weren't well-trained and educated, which resulted in mediocre level out from middle managers to avoid rocking the boat. 
Diversity didn't result in equality.

pros: I've been with the company for almost 5 years now, being here I have had so much opportunity to move around and expand my experience in different departments. The company has always recognized top performers and rewarded very well. The company is very flexible with time off, they have a great combination of work, balance, and life.

headline: Worst place to work in NYC

Most people pretend they work and nothing gets done. London rules everything, meetings are lengthy and get you nowhere. Promotions happen if you become friends with the right people not based on what and how you do things.

headline: It was a nice fun place to work but could have been better.

cons: night shifts only; cannot choose shifts; training time (a.m.) was different from production time (p.m.) so incurred more than allowed time discrepancies

headline: Work environment at HSBC Bank India
pros: Comfortable job. People generally don't work on weekends which is not the case for many other private sector banks in India. Well laid out HR Policies.
cons: Versatility and dynamism are often not looked for in Support functions like HR, Communication and Corporate Sustainability et al. Many employees work in a team or function for years and make a comfortable bubble around themselves. They go on adding no new value or fresh perspective to the working environment. They often turn the environment not so conducive for innovation, value addition and new initiatives.

headline: spent many years at this one company
pros: Large Co. with many benefits
cons: Large Co. with may departments.  Not easy to navigate.

headline: Very Good

headline: Great people, low morale
pros:
Hours can sometimes be flexible based on your department
Great people to work with
Potential to move up quickly with hard work
cons:
The fact that PHH is taking over most of this company in Buffalo has morale at a pretty low level. Future positions are unsure, along with some other disappointments, but from what I can tell they are mostly problems from PHH's side.
A lot of temporary workers right now means there can be frustrations dealing with high-turnover departments not fully knowing what they're doing. Again, it's just the situation the company's in and not much they can do about it.
Every second of your day is managed by a company system to calculate productivity- better not daydream too much

headline: not a really good place to work

cons: low pay, hierarchy is strict and performance is not always well measured

headline: Customer service
pros: Lots of works to choose from if you looking for opportunities.
cons: Have to be aggressive and know how to sell products to your clients if you wants to be a sales.

headline: Was Good, Then Became Bad & now UGLY
pros:
- Hands down experience of working in a huge setup
- Lot of learning and travel opportunities
cons:
- Bureaucratic in each and every aspect. From promotions to even getting a gate pass
- Senior management is clueless, un approachable and all they do is satisfy their massive egos.
- HR being the weakest link. They hardly would come out and support you incase you need any help.
- No check on promotions, same set of people get two promotions in four years, whereas there is no promotion in the team.

headline: Self motivation is required to develop and move up in your career

cons: Although there are the opportunities to try out many career, you growth path often depends on WHO you know in the bank.

headline: Good

cons: any change is quite slow

headline: Lots to learn but demanding

cons: No one would have spare time to teach you anything. You have to learn and perform yourself.

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: work life balance is great here :)
cons: With limited projects at hand the growth becomes stagnant

headline: Worst ever
pros: Big Corp and strong in Asia, but never in US
cons: micro management, they will turn you into a robot. Make you memorize elevator speaches to customers.

headline: Good pay compared to local banks

cons: Homegrown employees have low pay, not really much training for branch operations -you will learn through experience.

headline: not much advancement opportunities

cons: difficult  to move between departments

headline: it is quite challenging at times.
pros: There is a lot of diversity here and there are many opportunities for you to learn. It is challenging at times especially when you are dealing with sales and customer service.
cons:
There really isnt a set work shift schedule and you have to plan according to your own work schedule. 

 There should be more training for the employees in sales.

headline: A nightmare of a company
pros: A good salary (to keep people n the job) and benefits.
cons: If you've never worked anywhere else, this might seem like a great company to work for. However, if you've worked elsewhere, you'll see it for the nightmare it is!  There is NO training. The systems are outdated and antiquated so there is no way to 'figure things out' -- which explains why so many work 12 hr days sometimes 6 days a week just to keep up!!!  The extend of my training was to 'read the manual'. Turnover is EXTREMELY HIGH due to systems and management.

headline: Not So Good Employer
pros: There are a lot of opportunities before and good environment working with other employees.
cons: Job Security is not so good.  Unfair performance reviews - favoritism is very obvious.

headline: Do Not Come Here
pros: Company uses programs and industry standards so you will earn a ton of experience.
cons: Company is slowly relocating so don't bother applying because you may not be able to keep your job.

headline: IT Manager

cons: Complex organization structure slowing down decisions and requiring many IT roles to work extended hours to interact with colleagues overseas.

headline: HSBC
pros:
good benefits
possibility to move up

headline: Global Bank that needs more presence in the US market

cons: HSBC hasn't found a way to organize the business and bring various regions (UK, HK and US) together in order to help market the products.

1. Brand name - globally recognized organization

3. Good food (subsidized), Gym and other programs

1. No company transport.
2. Some laid back attitude among long timers.

headline: Summer intern

headline: Good company to work for provided you are honest, hard working and can get along well.
pros: Flexible working hours, smart co-workers and good project planning. Expect to work hard and efficiently if  you want to do well. You will also need to be able to communicate well and get along with colleauges.
cons: They only work with technologies that they approve of so it can be a little bit behind the curve. Heavy management. Hard work may not always be given due credit/reward although it may be acknowledged in words. Inter personal relationships may matter more at times.

headline: HSBC Global Markets is a great place to start your career as an Analyst in Sales or Trading.
pros: The culture facilitates work/life balance, encourages younger employees to work with senior management, and fosters improvement.
cons: Systems and other technology can sometimes be dated.  Many inefficiencies exist because of bureaucracy related to the US being a subsidiary of the London-based bank.

cons: Political and bureaucratic. Slow to make changes and lacking innovation.

headline: Decent retail experience
pros:
-Good formal training
-Benefits (tuition assistance, 401k match, insurance for PT employees)
-Good people at local branch
-Short workdays, especially on Monday-Thurs
cons:
-Pay is pretty low, but not too bad
-Local managers had a power issue
-Customers were often difficult to deal with during rough economic times. Due to the bank's policies about cashing H&R Block checks, etc., free of charge, we had to deal with some downright nasty situations involving people "wanting their money, now!!!"

headline: -Overall, a good company
pros:

cons:

headline: Disappointed
pros: One needs to really self train which in turn makes you an independent thinker.
cons: They do not request feedback on Sr Managers, who in turn have gotten into their roles by taking the credit for others.  The lack of understanding for other cultures was outstanding given that this is an international company. The work environment is quite toxic due to review structure and promotes an anti-team culture.

headline: One of the best, the biggest
pros: A company where you can comming long term
cons: Cant think of any apart from maybe too big corporation where you can really get lost.

headline: A great company to work for
pros: I've worked at HSBC for over 25 years.  Each time I needed a new challenge, I only had to look inside our company to find my next job.  The Bank is very supportive of their employees and is genuinely interested in their personal growth and development.  Where positions allow it, they offer the best work-life balance you could find.
cons: I can't think of any downside to working at HSBC.  Truly enjoy my job and my team.

headline: So far So good and getting better

headline: Shortsighted Management
pros: Being located at One HSBC Center in downtown Buffalo, you had access to walk along the waterfront and also had access to a few good places to eat downtown.
cons: Those with the greatest ability to lie, back stab and think 'inside' the box and always say yes to management had the greatest potential to advance their careers.  Intelligent, independent thinkers who challenge the status quo need not apply.

Some great people

headline: It's a OK place to work
pros: Great international exposure, significant workload that can enrich your experience and colleagues that don't mind helping. Good banking benefits to staff compared to other local banks in Canada however this benefit is on the decline.
cons: Very poor management structure that is confused between going global or staying local. No proper focus on any activity or business process. The technology division is divided into fiefdoms with a small diminishing camp of do'ers and a growing population of only talkers. Limited (read as no)  career opportunities, little to no pay reviews and average bonus. Definitely pay way below market and they don't care, they believe being global gives them access to cheap labour. However with going cheap, quality suffers, Low employee morale across the organisation. Lacks dynamism and definitely hates dynamic employees as they push the envelope that makes sr.management uncomfortable.

headline: Not bad, but HSBC is too huge. Hard to comment.
pros: Financially stable company, good culture (work-life balance). Good reputation, values add on to career. Lots of training opportunities. Good international exposure.
cons: Too many red tapes. The subsidiary of HSBC may have different structure and management style, hence the problems come. The management team is very political.

headline: Life changing

headline: Large company not in touch with its employees.
pros: Diverse culture, tuition reimbursement and 401k benefits, generous amount of vacation days.
cons: Company is so large, that employees feel like a number.  Management continuously implements new procedures without getting feedback from employees first, causing many problems with the process that have to be patched along the way.  Employee advocacy is almost non existent.  Middle management continues to throw employees under the bus to make themselves look better.  Barely any leadership found in middle management.  Communication between departments that rely on each other is terrible.  Roles and responsibilities are unclear.  Very difficult for young professionals to move up in the organization even if they are top performers.

headline: On a tight leash
pros: You can work from home if you make up a good excuse. Hours are not long and you rarely work overtime. The day starts around 8am or 8:30am and ends around 5pm or 5:30pm
cons: You do not get promoted for working hard; instead you get promoted for being good at "talking" or "b.s." In other words, as long as you can talk the talk, you don't need to walk the walk. Another con is the "clean-desk" policy - everything you leave your desk, computers and desk drawers need to be locked and papers should not be left out, otherwise someone can anonymously report you to management.

headline: Good
pros:
The benefits are pretty good. Provides health insurance and stock purchase at a discount.
Work life balance is decent, but largely depending on manager.
A lot of day offs provided per year, even for new employees.
Training is pretty good. A lot of classes offered both technical and non technical.
Employee engagement is good, senior management is trying its best to listen to the low level employees and hear them out.
Fellow employees are pretty friendly and easy to get along with. There is not much cut throat competition.
HSBC offers special banking benefits to employees.
cons:
Promotions is biased. It is based on who brown noses the best and favoritism rather than on merit.
A lot of the managers do not know anything about what they are managing thus making a big joke of everything and leaving everything for the analysts to figure out.
Some managers are strict about taking day offs. Thus negating the purpose of having a lot of day offs. 
Cafeteria food is overpriced and inedible. Work location is in the middle of nowhere - long commute times.

pros: Genuinely tries to put customer first. Sincere desire among management to develop each individual. Well structured management makes for effective leadership and direct accountability.

headline: Job Stability is dependent on the tenure of current Management
pros:
The biggest pro is that you are working for HSBC
The second biggest pro is that the campus is cool
The third biggest pro is that the food in the campus is good
The fourth biggest pro is that the facilities are well maintained and properly secured
cons:
The constant shift in management of the HSBC Group creates chaos in HSBC GLT.
HSBC is after all a bank and it will do anything and everything to show a profit, which includes firing people left, right and center.
HSBC GLT has lost a lot of money on many initiatives that failed. The only people benefiting in these failed ventures are the top level management. Although they are asked to quit, but these guys make a lot of money to suffice for a life time before they quit. This has been a constant in HSBC GLT since 2008 to 2011. The current CEO change has ensured that this has come down to a minimum but still what was lost earlier is hard to recover.
New management has tightened the screws everywhere, but it is only adding to severe employee unrest. Although this has ensured minimal malpractices, but it has increased the frustration in employees.

headline: The ship is sinking...
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, good bonuses, lots of overtime available, not open 24/7, cafeteria, clean, ample parking, good location, nice lobby, security.
cons: I was hired as a collections rep II.  From what was blatantly said by senior management HSBC is liquidating their mortgage portfolios and there are no plans to generate new ones.  They have been fined for regulation violations (predatory lending) and are looking to sell the portfolio altogether.  This has already been done w/ their credit card portfolio.  The time frame given 'long term' was three years, so don't plan on being there long.  I believe HSBC is a wonderful company to be employed with, if you are in a higher up position.  For  collections and customer service they're simply hiring bodies at this point to help liquidate the portfolio before it is sold.  This has led to very lax employment requirements, in my training class I witnessed racial slurs "that's just one more white person I can check off my list, I don't like them anyway", obscenities, markers and such being thrown, passing gas loudly and purposely in the elevator, and sexual comments as well.  I believe there would be less disorder in a prison yard.  The employees who have been there for a while seem to be equally disgusted in the new-hire classes.  One last thing, the dress code is neither interpreted or enforced, much of the time I felt as if I was in a club; abundances of cleavage, spandex, six inch platform heels, bamboo earrings, bright orange hair, tattoos,etc. (see posted pic).  If you are at all looking for a job that utilizes skills or education go elsewhere.  If you're looking to get in and out and make some fast money in the next couple years then this would be a good place for you (the job itself isn't that bad if you can make it through the god-awful subjugation of the training class).

headline: HSBC still the best place to WORK
author_position: Assistant Vice President for Global Resourcing
pros: Been in this industry for 18 yrs, 4 of those was with HSBC and it was by far the best working experience I have ever had. HS listens to people's feedback through GPS, treats the front-liners fairly and is a very generous company. As one of the Senior Leader of HSBC Global Resourcing in the Philippines I have never worked of a greater company than HSBC
cons: When I joined HSBC in 2007 my first comment to my SVP Nikkie Harris was that we have such a small span of control and that we are VERY top HEAVY.  I felt at that time that I was not relevant as an AVP since I was only managing 100FTE with 3 Managers under me. I mentioned that this type of span will not be profitable to any company. It has to make some drastic change before the CEOs and the CFOs realize this and demands a quick resolution which will be very unpopular to the greater percentage of the workforce. A yr after that, my VP left for another company but he was replaced with not one for TWO VPs. Imagine my surprise that even with so many Senior Managers in the office 2 were still promoted for a single open post.  Fast forward to 2011 when  Stuart Gulliver announced selling of HouseHold to Cap 1 and  the mandate to streamline the organization. The same strategy I was pointing out 4 years ago.

headline: Horrible - Unsupportive, stuck in old ways, HSBC has no interest in US
pros: HSBC is a top global banking brand.  Anyone with any banking or commercial knowledge knows that.  Once you finally want to get out of HSBC, it looks great on your resume.  If you are lucky enough to get laid off, they treat you well and give you good severance. Also can work from home. occasionally
cons:
1.  HSBC in US is a dying cause:  The only area the company places major focus on is commercial banking arm.  Retail banking and GB&M are both shrinking in size (though still will exist), and all of the finance company has either been sold off or is in run off.  There is opportunity to move up, but if you want to work in an environment where everyone is on their toes for lay offs, then that is up to you.
2.  The atmosphere supports no entrepreneurial attitude or creativity in your job (at the staff/manager level).  They just want someone to complete part of the process, and they could care less about what you can bring to the table or who you are as a person.
3.  The office is really nice, but it is in the middle of no where.  No body socializes at work due to the uptight office culture (although gossiping is worse than it was in HS), and certainly no body goes out after work for happy hour.  
4.  Just a depressing atmosphere in general - everybody in this office knows lay offs already have or are soon to occur and that HSBC USA is not mainstream HSBC at all.  We are a portion of a global bank that is a major drag on group consolidated earnings (due to our mortgage portfolio).

headline: Not on a permanent basis
pros: HSBC has good medical benefits, covered by ING. I also happpened to have one of the best contact centre manager in my  department, a young person who is able to inspire the all team members, open to ideas and still able to be a good leader.
cons:
Their salary both basic and allowances are low compared to what is being offered in the market. They are not able to retain their staff hence burdens the current employees with an overload of work. This is especially true in contact centres, it creates a very stressfull working environment. And do keep in mind there are a huge number of people who work in the night shift, which changes a lot if things in their lifes, they need to be compansation for that.
HSBC also has the policy of hiring college graduates with degrees and school leavers for the same position and offer them the same salary, regardless if their academic qualifications. It creates an unease among co workers, and as a result they tend to leave the company.

headline: Lots of Opportunity, Good Pay, Decent Benefits, as long as you're not part of IT and in NYC
pros: HSBC pays well, they provide decent benefits, and they have implemented a work from home program, to make sure employees who are in positions that allow this perk the ability to experience true work/life
cons:
They treat their IT division, HTS, like unwanted step children.  Unfortunately, if you are part of IT and  you're based in NYC, their is almost no opportunity for advancement or job rotation.  You will be stuck doing the same thing, day in and day out, no matter your skill level.  In order to move  up or experience working on different technology, you will need to be willing to relocate out of state or country.   If you want any chance at doing something different, but are determined to stay in NYC, you have to wait for someone to vacate a position, because they rarely create new positions for HTS in NYC. 

Chances are that you'll be reporting to someone in Buffalo, NY, Mettawa, IL, or Vancouver Canada.  Your team will probably be spread through these locations as well.  Therefore, your relationship with your manager(s) and colleagues can suffer.  

If you have exceptional skill in your field of  IT expertise, this is not the company for you.  Their processes and refusal to allow you to grow will dumb you down to the point of self doubt.  

Lastly, HTS members are always the first lambs led to the slaughter when the company decides that it is necessary to cut jobs.

cons: There is not much to say. The only thing that I would comment on is that because of the size of the company, it's hard to have close relations with the people from different departments.

headline: worked for hsbc for about 9 years. I was a retail banking manager and a corporate banking manager.
pros: The experience and training programs that you get in hsbc is the best. Being an international bank, it exposes you to several experiences that other local banks do not have. The system of having limits for corporate clients to be approved locally and over these limits to be approved by the headquarters gives the bank strength with minimum risks.
cons: Mangement discrimination with employees ad mangement self interests do exist unfortunately.

headline: The dawn of life
pros: In here, it seems I'm not in a office rather in a get together with friends. All are helpful with their own field of expertise, ready to give shoulder when you need one and always helps to explore the unexplored.
cons: Sometimes you might feel gloomy regarding work pressure, sometimes you might feel demotivated. But sharing your thoughts always brightens up the day.

headline: HSBC India
pros:
HSBC is Good Payer
5 Day a Week
cons: No prmotion on the basis of performance in same department you have to apply for a internal jobs oppening.

headline: Very Enriching and great
pros: Employee centric and dynamic work culture & environment

headline: extremely unhappy working with the people of the  group
pros:
Brand name and the number of years HSBC has stood as a solid bank is a big advantage, the trust clients have on HSBC, client service was very good. 
compliance and the process to check mis selling was a plus point for the organization.
cons:
too much of in house politics, back stabbing bosses who are constantly looking at opportunities to grab the productive client accounts to be mapped to them.
Also on the product side no indepth research on equities and clueless in terms of calls to be taken in asset allocation

headline: well compensated.
pros: I like my current company because it's more convenient for me financially and it is also near my place.

headline: Amazing systems.... Badly managed....

cons: There is total disconnect between upper management and lower. Overall employee satisfaction is very low since the last three years. Too many changes in a financial year and overall incentive is decreasing year by year.

cons: Sell sell sell. This is all that seems to matter nowadays. Bonuses are reducing year on year and even staff breaks are being reduced from 15 mins to 10

headline: Just a job
pros: Work/life balance. Flexibility to work remotely. Benefits package. Respect for personal circumstances. Good place if you think you have reached your professional ceiling and your only aspiration is to take care of your family and make some good money.
cons: No salary increases for four straight years. No career advancement opportunities. Department full of mediocre individuals. Senior manager rewards brown nowsing while pervasive mediocrity is accepted. Empty promises.

headline: Company does not care about its employees

cons:
- company uses you as much as possible to provide numbers, you become expendable when you don't meet targets. 
- a lot of changes and restructuring to save costs, limited bonuses and promotion
- likes to hire outside the company, promotion from within is dependent on whether or not management likes you

headline: The World's Local Bank
pros: Benefits are on par with other banks (or slightly better). Hours are not too bad in general.
cons: As the name calls, it is a bureaucratic workplace stuff with generation of 50-60s. People tend to stick with groups whom they know for ages, rather than accepting new comers in a welcoming open-minded manner. Reluctant to change. Government like culture i.e. people go to work just to prepare for their retirement. Not an exciting place for people who want stimulation. To be fair, it may also depends on your boss's mindset. If you get an open-minded boss, you are lucky. But luck just doesn't appear in every team.

headline: Not sure what to put here
pros: Good benefits, hard working colleagues
cons: too many cooks in the kitchen, old school employees had a hard time adjusting to new ways of thinking.

headline: Challenging, thought provoking
pros: Working in a multinational organization is always a dream as you are know to everyone as you are part of something renowned. Always ahead of other organization in innovation in technology and products.
cons: You become very specific in your job and always go for specialization in your area of expertise and ypu have a very little knowledge of other areas.

headline: Having a good Opportunity to discover yourself
pros: Good ambience, cleanliness ans sanitation maintained and great work environment
cons: poor management skills at times can hinder your work

headline: Challenging and requires a lot of commitment.
pros: Its a global platform, with low industry risk. It has a great working environment with a reasonable payscale.
cons: Functions are strictly specialized until somebody has risen up the ladder.

headline: Awesome....would love to work there again
pros: Awesome Work culture,flexible timings & cubicles
cons: Patheic canteen food,Very rigid in shift change

headline: Blah
pros: Casual dress code, ok wages
cons: With all the changes going on, the higher ups kept everyone in the dark

headline: Let's have a meeting about a meeting.
pros: A good brand name. External employers think of it as a bastion of excellence.
cons:
It's a bureaucratic nightmare. 
People are over promoted. Far too many people at GCB4 and too many people at GCB3 who should be demoted and told to actually do some work.
There is no downside to not doing a good job. This company tolerates underperformance.
The turnover of good people is horrific. If they actually developed their top talent, they wouldn't be left with a bank that is riddled with people that have been there for 15 years plus and think they know EXACTLY how the place should work. They lack perspective.
Know this - the only thing management give a monkeys about is progressing their career. 
Don't tell HR anything you wouldn't tell the CEO to his face. They are his henchmen.

headline: General Banking Officer
pros: Sfficient benefits and trainning to employees
cons: Working late. Too much stress and too many targets.

headline: Difficult
pros: good salary, some excellents peers, my direct boss is excelent, as guide and as friend, I adore my job, I like to help people to resolve their problems
cons: Many times there are bad branch managers, specialy mine, he is not qualified to lead a branch or tu have people in charge. There is no relationship between the service that the bank promotes with  the number of workers it has in the branches and leaves much to be desired attention we can provide to customers, since the systems are obsolete

headline: HSBC is the best place to work

headline: Fairly good company to work with
pros: Good work culture, Good pay master though not the best, Good work life balance. Performance driven company. Provides platform to exhibit interpersonal skills.
cons: A company is only as good as its people and policies. While the policies are quite in place it may not always be easier to find the right people to drive them properly.

headline: It's the worlds' local bank
pros: The graduate program is totally worth it. The sky is your limit, especially if your point of hire is in Europe, North and South America as well as Hong Kong to some extent. As far as my knowledge goes, hitherto HSBC Australia is yet to have one and doesn't even acknowledge the program. One of the big loopholes that the Group must solve.
cons:
Office politics is entrenched in some sites, on the upside this is a good place to hone your soft skills.
I have a bad experience with how my works and experience were not acknowledged at all in HSBC Australia when I applied for different available roles which were very similar roles with the ones that I've done in couple HSBC's sites.

cons: Benefits, package and opportunities, growth

headline: Good company culture

cons: Hard to move within departments if your boss does not want to let you go, and you get the feeling that some people are already pre selected for this

headline: Over employed & Bengali corporation
pros: Brand image & nothing more. Employees pretend to be ethical very easily (Which they are not).
cons: No proper system, over populated for the same job (Too many managers doing micro management)

headline: Large organization that means well but doesn't execute very well

cons: It can be hard for your voice to be heard in such a large organization. Often feels like senior management has no idea what is going on on the front lines. Bank politics often plays a big decision in projects, etc. Some management refuses to talk to others 'not on their level'.

headline: people oriented, need to improve rewards for meritocracy
pros: it's a people centric organisation , company has it's vision is right, there is fun at work, and overall the company is concerned about customers and employees upto a certain extent.
cons: Need to develop a strong meritocracy based reward system. Transparency at senior mangement level will instill confidence in employees and get them to perform better.

headline: HSBC was like a second home to me.
pros: Work environment was great. People with different backgrounds were working together & were treated the same. Other departments were also quite co-operative.
cons: Very less salary & no promotions. I worked there for 3 years in the same position, though i was the best, even got a team player certificate in the 1st quarter, which is quite sad!

headline: HSBC was like a second home to me.
pros: Work environment was great. People with different backgrounds were working together & were treated the same. Other departments were also quite co-operative.
cons: Very less salary & no promotions. I worked there for 3 years in the same position, though i was the best, even got a team player certificate in the 1st quarter, which is quite sad!

headline: Not a bad place to work if you don't expect too much from the bank.
pros: HSBC is probably the most culturally diverse international banks in the US. Strong international connection. Plenty of internal transfer or job rotation opportunities to broaden your skill set and exposure. Strong focus on values at the high level.
cons: Deep hierarchy and silo greatly minimizes the effectiveness of the organization. Does not encourage knowledge sharing, making silo effect worse. Lack of consistent business strategy. Too big and too complicated to make it effective.

headline: It is a place where I can grow not only professionally but intellectually and where training and education is available
pros: I would have all the necessary equipment i.e.: computer, scanner, fax and phone to do my job effectively. My schedule would be flexible and my work hours would be filled with productivity. I excel in an environment that has good communication skills and great teamwork but I enjoy working independently. My supervisor would be employee friendly with great communication skills and could coach and lead me to meet common and rewarding goals
cons:
Bankers tend to err on the side of caution. This conservatism may not appeal to many fresh MBAs who are looking for dynamic, business development kind of jobs right from day one.
They give you only a limited choice of final posting or function at the entry level

headline: Great company
pros:
Great culture
Very good management
Data driven
Good policy towards employees
cons:
Slow on innovation
Focus more on customer research

headline: Bureaucratic & Slow-Moving, but maybe getting better
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Awesome opportunities for global mobility
cons:
- Career progression is based on networking and/or being in the right place at the right time, rather than skills & ability, because HR does not have any oversight of what different employees bring to the table
- Unimaginable levels of bureaucracy

headline: Genuine banking experience
pros: You can easily integrate the team with a very professional atmosphere. The communication system within the organisation, using the lotus notes, is very efficient and easy to use.
cons: You have many deadlines to meet. Sure, the managers are friendly. But if you miss a deadline, you'll have to pay for it. Usually, they do that by giving you a low rating during the appraisal process and so you get a lower bonus.

headline: Good place to work

* Best Job Profiles
* Best Yearly Bonuses

headline: OK place to work
pros: Very large international bank; focus in the US is on commercial banking and wealth management.  If you are open to international postings or multilingual, this could be a very good company for you.
cons: Conservative, risk adverse, laying off many US employees in non-core businesses, very slow to change, salary growth last few years was either non-existant or pathetic.

headline: Not the best player in Broking business. Poor Management
pros: Exposure to move within HSBC Group is very high if you excel in your assignment at hand.
cons: Broking business is not doing well due to wrong approach towards the broking products. Hence not a good broking player in the industry.

headline: Same apathy from employees across HDPI locations.
pros: Advantages are there and above average, as discussed earlier varied work culture and different skill sets. One will find employees ranging from graduates to chattered accountants. One can really explore different employment chances and scopes here. Good place to work and learn.
cons: But seems the shine of this work culture is being covered up by the common apathy of employees across locations. Words like diplomacy and politics are sounding time and again. Employees seemed to be annoyed and frustrated with the politics and biased decision of the management.  Came across few reviews to be precise 67 in a week and everyone have the same problem description in the reviews. No respect for employees, no value for employee’s loyalty and dedication, politics and application of double standards. Company adopts a kind of closed door policy.

headline: Learned a lot being surrounded by some of the most gifted colleagues
pros: Company is filled with smart and friendly colleagues. Many of them are ex-consultants and top recruits from leading companies. They are willing to wait for the right talent and pay good money to get them onboard. Can learn a lot from direct managers. Large scope of work gives good general management experience. In general, company has very good intention to treat it customers the way they would want their own grandmother to be treated. Very strong supporter of environmental causes.
cons: Strategy shifts drastically when CEO changes. Consensus driven culture leading lack of accountablity. Every small decisions have to float up to London. In order to "manage better from London", silos were created which made environment very difficult to get things accomplished. In the US, bank failed to creat a strong brand despite operation in the country for over 25 years.

cons: Poor rating system. Poor training. Zero cross training. After 7 years with HSBC I am still unable to find a job within the IT industry because HSBC took no effort to train me to do anything but my day-today job. Very little room to move between departments or gain new experience.

headline: Best place to work.. but
pros:
Excellent environment to work from!
Cafeteria+
breakout areas on each floor++
great people
At least one R&R session per month!
enough holidays! which includes 10 working days leave that YOU will have to take at a stretch!
cons:
initial salary.. I am a fresher and wanted to join a company with good repute to kick start my career. HSBC gave me that platform (thankyou!).. BUT.. the initial salary offered by the company is really low, even though they will claim that it is compitetive for that job role!

bonuses work on a bell curve, which means, at least one bottom performer for the team will not recieve a salary hike! I found that to be a little strange..

severe competition is generated by this. Even though this is good, finding growth in the organisation really tough!

headline: Experience speaks

Best part of the Co was its retention policy & leave policy which are so employee centric
Elderly people who come to work are dealt with great patience and care so that they do not feel that they are less efficient..
cons:
Downsides of late have increased...it differs from location to location and surely the individuals who help the co grow are the ones who are responsible for its upliftment

Politics
Rating the individuals through a method which leaves them nowhere and demoralised
Lack of leadership qualities in the managers
Promotions have become a gimmick
honesty is severely dealt with
Unfair treatment
Policies are amended not for the benefit of employees but for the management may be....

headline: They're Laying Off Like Crazy in Buffalo, NY Right Now
pros: When I worked hard and made extra efforts I was compensated for it (bonuses, raises)...but never promoted.  It's the luck of the draw though - depending on who your direct managers & supervisors are (see Cons below).
cons: Well the main con is that they're laying off like crazy right now and probably won't be in Buffalo past 2013.  They got rid of 1500-2000 with the Capital One sale (this includes other sites around the country). And in the past two weeks about 200-500 more HSBC Buffalo employees have been laid off.  I  wouldn't be surprised if hundreds if not thousands more will be laid off by the end of this year due to the sale of the branches to First Niagara last weekend.  On to other cons...HSBC likes to move uneducated management around within the company - managers from one dept to another who have no clue about their new dept. and also promote people who have no college and/or don't have enough experience of the job.  Why do they do this?  Because then they don't have to pay what the job is worth, because that would require hiring someone with a degree and/or previous management experience in that field who would require a lot more money.  When management doesn't have a clue about the job, it trickles down and makes everyone's lives miserable.  (see 'Advice to Management' for a continuation of this).   This is Buffalo I'm talking about, maybe it's different in NYC...

headline: Depending on department, reminds me of being in High school
pros: Great benefits chance to grow in your career and extensive training opportunities
cons:
Underwriters and Processor Associates act as if everything should be handed to them on a silver platter. The people who have been with the company for less than 5 years have a better outlook than the 20+ year-still-in-the-same-job-because-of-their-own-lack-of-motivation-and-constant-whining. That really was the worst part of working there. 

These "old timers" act as if their is a conspiracy, when management breaks their necks trying to keep people happy...which is absurd. It makes for an undesirable, high school like atmosphere that makes you dread coming to work. My advice - get rid of the complainers and start fresh with people who appreciate the fact that they have a job. 

I have never worked for a company where mangement goes overboard like this trying to keep staff happy. Gift cards, free lunches, lots of meetings and an open door policy and the funny thing is, the biggest complainers probably get the least amount of work done, yet expect the world to be handed to them. 

THAT is why morale is rotten. It is the staff not management that needs to be fixed.

Some employees do not have the finances or means to be able to continue their education.

Employees are told no raise but some secretly get them-most do not.  Everyone in the branch who is not on the teller line thinks they are in charge of the tellers which makes for a divided workplace.  Sales are VERY important. Without them no raises and no advancment.

headline: Professional groups motivated by successful project completions.

headline: An Ok experience

headline: Company restructuring to align with parent company expectations
pros: HSBC is a great brand on resume with international opportunities for above average employees.  The organization has a clear value proposition for business with international requirements.  HSBC Bank Canada is also a relatively "flat" organization with ample access to senior management.
cons: The organization does not have a meaningful scale in the retail market and does not have a clear value proposition beyond niche commercial market - this contributes to somewhat limited opportunties for growth and increased uncertainty around job security.  There is also substantial pressure to reduce costs and head count from the parent company as HSBC is presently in the process of eliminating over 30,000 positions globally.

headline: If you want to grow technically, HSBC GLT will be a wrong choice, otherwise good choice if you want to be a resource mgr
pros:
- Work Life Balance (plenty of it and you will be bored some times for doing nothing)
- Salary Hike (you get a nice hike in comparison to most of the companies - not all obviously)
- Onsite (chances are good)
- Good place to grow in if you want to be an administrative & resource manager
- HSBC Brand
cons:
- HR has a very little say, most of the times things are in the hand of delivery manager (BU Head) or department head, although otherwise some HR policies are good.
- Very less opportunities if somebody wants to grow technically (definitely a wrong place for any good technical person).
- Since there is no very clear guideline in terms of the skill set up-gradation & training and If you do not keep your eyes/ mind open, after few year chances would be high that there may not be any taker (employer) for you.

headline: Great work experience, too bad about the economy.  Big layoffs
pros: The compay had a great compensation plan which included a nice salary and bonus structure.  Work environment was positive depending on your manager but overall nice job.
cons: The cons were that you had to work some weekends and late on some days up until about 7pm.  But not that bad.

headline: Unfulfilling, lower pay than market
pros: Steady job, you will have a set career path. The organizational structure within sales and trading is very hierarchical, and if you put the time in, you will advance.
cons: Very hierarchical, producers are not rewarded fairly. They will consistently pay below the market, even when other banks have done poorly and this bank has done well.

headline: IT  was a good learning experience. Good to start of as a college graduate
pros:
HSBC has a very good brand name.
Besides they are very flexible with the work hours ( atleast most of the teams with FT employees). Has good benefit packages. and they are a very employee friendly company.
cons:
A little laid back culture.
Ideal  if you have a family but you would want to do more interesting if you are single.
At least within a couple of teams, work is the same over the years. Nothing new is taken up.

headline: Excellent experience to have a taste of banking

Friendly people
good pay compared to other banks
cons:
Bureaucratic
too big 
slow decision making somtimes

headline: Sometimes Good, Sometimes Not....
pros:
great office environment 
good benefits (kind of)
innovative thinkers
well respected global brand
marketable to future employers
efforts towards global programs
cons:
awful management in HR
poor communication
lack of transparency
bad, not actually awful on boarding experience
poor pay
no recognition for delivery of work
expected to work incredibly long hours
old boys (and girls) club - not welcoming to new people

HSBC is an amazing brand, and externally it is seen as an amazing place to have on your resume, unfortunately in my experience is was entirely the opposite, the worst place I have ever worked for nearly every reason imaginable.  The only plus is that there are some amazing people there, skilled, talented, and professional but sadly they aren't words i'd use for any of the management staff in the HR team.

headline: Much transition and job elimination leading to very difficult work environment
pros: Benefits, salary, training, work-at-home policy, global opportunities
cons: Challenging work ethic, US company undergoing numerous reductions causing difficult work environment

headline: Challenging
pros: Solid Benefits and  pension plan
cons:
The organization is very large, slow to move. Management does not have an adequate understanding  US market. Not a meritocracy at all. Promotions are given to those with most "political collateral" or mindless sheep. Business lines to do not work cohesively. There is no sense of urgency to assists clients. IT functions out of India  are hopelessly incompetent . There is no room for creativity , or  outside the box thinking. There is no rigor or risk management  analysis , when either rolling out a simple  product marketing campaign or the purchase of a lending institution.The company has a long history and very poor track record  of entering either geographic markets or client segments with shoddy execution and poor metrics of success. The company has zero regard for its employees and staff. Senior management changes are constant, and disruptive to execution and employee moral. Training is very limited and delivered by people who are average performers.
An independent thinker, entrepreneurial mindset is not welcome. There is no defined culture  It is impossible to "drink the kool aid"  because  executive management can not agree on a flavor.

headline: Motivational job experience
pros: Provides insightful and strategic thinking experience on how funds transfer operations affects the way regulatory sanctions programs are applied within global institutions
cons: Some limitations to working at hsbc is that the internal structure is somewhat rigid in terms of career diversification programs

headline: Slow but a good place to be
pros: Employee focus is very good. Its a huge organisation, so lot of opportunities, if you work hard & look around.
cons: Decision making takes time. And a lot of time. Tenure is not a highly valued organisation asset and this leads to loss of good staff. New blood is important, but you also need the guys who knows the nuts & bolts of the company

headline: Good career opportunities but you need to fight super hard and you are on your own to make it happen
pros:
-  decent (but not great) overall compensation package
-  huge organization with plenty of  upward opportunities (worldwide)
-  very structured and policy driven (if you like it)
cons:
-  SUPER SUPER bureaucratic (10 layers of approvals to buy a roll of toilet paper)
-  as a result, strategies are very "safe" but the structure kills any innovative idea
-  guidelines everywhere (supposingly for good corporate governance and encourage best practice sharing but turns out to be excuses for people not to do things and people create long and overly-detailed guidelines just to justify their job and importance)
-  no support at all from senior management for your career growth.  Senior management are smart but they only care about themselves.
-  yes, there are opportunities to go upwards but you need to work so so hard on your own to build relationships and create opportunities

headline: It's is hard to secure a good job in today's market this was diff a great place to work
pros: It has a lot of great benefits including a pension.
cons: HSBC is selling to capital one I do not know what the company will look like in the future so I decided to leave.

headline: Lacks entrepreneur spirit
pros: A big company that rewards group think. If you work long hours and agree with corporate direction, you will do OK here. They do not reward creative thinking or outside the box thinking.
cons: They dismiss / sever employees with little regard to value or long term benefit to company. The focus is on keeping salaries low and making employees work long hours.

headline: Good but potential to be Amazing!
pros: One of the best brands in the world. Unlimited career opportunities product, function, geography (including international). Very smart people, from top down. Large budgets, progressive managers.
cons: Given scale, bank account, and depth, have the capability to be an A+ best places to work I.e. employee leadership and career development. HSBC says employees are number 1 but probably are about a couple generations behind. Scale works to disadvantage given lack of speed to market. HSBC proudly says they don't want to be first to market.
